div.head: THE FIRST ACT

stage.stage: The drawing-room of the villa occupied by MARIA LOUISA . The walls are painted al fresco in bright colors . The frieze is decorated with a design of sphinxes .

At the back , between two other windows , a window reaching to the ground and forming the entrance from the garden . Beyond , the balustrade of the terrace leading into the garden ; a glimpse of lindens and pine-trees . A magnificent day in the beginning of September . Empire furniture of lemonwood decorated with bronze . A large china stove in the centre of the wall on the left . In front of it a door . On the right , two doors . The first leads to the apartments of MARIA LOUISA . In front of the window on the left at the back an Erard piano of the period , and a harp . A big table on the right , and against the right wall a small table with shelves filled with books . On the left , facing the audience , a Récamier couch , and a large stand for candlesticks . A great many flowers in vases . Framed engravings on the walls representing the members of the Imperial Family of Austria . A portrait of the Emperor Francis .

At the rise of the curtain a group of elegant ladies is discovered at the further end of the room . Two of them are seated at the piano , with their backs to the audience , playing a duet . Another is at the harp . They are playing at sight , amid much laughter and many interruptions . A lackey ushers in a modestly dressed young girl who is accompanied by an officer of the Austrian Cavalry . Seeing that no one notices their entrance , these two remain standing a moment in a corner . The COUNT DE BOMBELLES comes in from the door on the right and goes toward the piano . He sees the young girl , and stops , with a smile .

sp.speaker: THE LADIES
sp.p: Surrounding the piano , laughing , and all talking at the same time .She misses all the flats !— It 's scandalous !— I 'll take the bass !— Loud pedal !— One ! Two !— Harp !

lg.l: What ! You !
Mi , sol .
The flats !

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: My dear Theresa ! Nothing ! You are my relative , and you are French .

lg.l: Tiburtius —

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: Ah , your brother !He gives him his hand and pushes forward a chair for THERESA .Take a seat .

lg.l: Heavens ! What about ?
To venture near the persons of the two
The Emperor left !

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: Oh , is that all , my child ?

sp.speaker: TIBURTIUS
sp.p: Our people hated Bonaparte of old —

lg.l: And perhaps
His son ?
Why , it would mean
I 'd never thought or read , and was not French ,
Nor born in recent years , if I could stand
Unmoved so near them . Is she lovely ?
She 's sad
And that itself is beauty .

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: But I 'm puzzled . Surely you 've seen her ?

lg.l: We feared we might disturb these ladies
Whose laughter sings new gamuts to the piano .

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: Here in my corner I await her notice .

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: What ? Why , it 's she who 's playing bass this moment !

div.stage: He goes to the piano and whispers to one of the ladies who are playing .

lg.l: Ah ! this child —
Quite a pathetic story — yes — you told me :
A brother —
The Austrian uniform is to my taste ;
And then there 's fox-hunting , which I adore .
So that 's the rascal whose extravagance
Eats up your little fortune ?

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: The wretch has ruined you , but you forgive him ! Theresa de Loget , I think you 're charming !She takes THERESA by both hands and makes her sit beside her on the couch .BOMBELLES and TIBURTIUS retire to the back .Now you 're among my ladies . I may boast I 'm not unpleasant ; rather sad at times Since —

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: I am grieved beyond the power of words .

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: Yes , to be sure . It was a grievous loss . That lovely soul was little known !

lg.l: I 've just been writing ; they 're to keep his horse —
Since the dear General 's death —

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: That title was his greatest glory .

lg.l: One cannot know at first all one has lost ;
And I lost all when General Neipperg died .
I came to Baden for distraction .
It 's nice . So near Vienna .— Ah , my dear ,
My nerves are troublesome ; they say I 'm thinner —
And growing very like Madame de Berry .
‘ Twas Vitrolles said so . Now I do my hair
Like her . Why did not Heaven take me too ?
This villa 's small , of course ; but ‘ tis n't bad ;
Metternich is our guest in passing .

div.stage: She points to the door on the left .

lg.l: He leaves to-night . The life at Baden 's gay .
We have the Sandors and the pianist Thalberg ,
And Montenegro sings to us in Spanish .
Fontana howls an air from Figaro .
The wife of the Ambassador of England
And the Archduchess come ; we go for drives —
But nothing soothes my grief !— Ah , could the General —!
Of course you 're coming to the ball to-night ?

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: At the Meyendorffs ’ . Strauss will be there . She must be present , must n't she , Bombelles ?

lg.l: May I solicit of your Majesty
News of the Duke of Reichstadt ?
In good health .
He coughs a little ; but the air of Baden
Is good for him . He 's quite a man . He 's reached
The critical hour of entrance in the world !
Oh dear ! when I consider he 's already
Lieutenant-Colonel ! Think how grieved I am
Never to have seen him in his uniform !

div.stage: Enter the DOCTOR and his son , bringing a box .

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: Ah ! These must be for him !

lg.l: Yes ; when I was visiting
This amiable old man , the local doctor ,
I saw his boy arranging these collections .
I sighed aloud , Alas ! would but my son ,
Whom nothing moves , take interest in these !
So then I answered , Well , your Majesty ,
One never knows . Why not ? We can but try ;
I 'll bring my butterflies !
Could he but leave his solitary musings
To occupy his mind with —
Leave them ; come back ; he 's out at present .
You
Come , I 'll present you to Scarampi . She 's
The Mistress of the Robes .
lg.stage: She sees METTERNICH , who enters L .
lg.l: Ah , Metternich !
Dear Prince , we leave you the saloon .
Indeed ,
I had to come here to receive the Envoy —
Of General Belliard , French Ambassador ;
And Councillor Gentz , and several Estafets .
With your permission —
First , Baron von Gentz .

div.stage: She goes out with THERESA . TIBURTIUS and BOMBELLES follow her . GENTZ enters .

lg.l: Good-morning , Gentz . You know
The Emperor recalls me to Vienna ?
I 'm going back to-day .
Yes ; it 's tiresome —
The town in summer !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Oh , come now ! No offence , you know , but — eh ? Surely the Russian Government has —

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Be frank . Who 's bought you ? Eh ?

lg.l: The highest bidder .

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: Smelling at a scent-bottle he has taken out of his pocket .In riotous living .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Good Heavens ! And you 're considered my right hand !

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: Let not your left know what your right receives .

lg.l: Why , yes , of course .
I 've money ; I love sweets and perfumes . Yes ,
I 'm a depraved old baby .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Affectation ! Mere pose of self-contempt .Suddenly .And Fanny ?

lg.l: Elssler ? Wo n't love me . I 'm ridiculous
From every point of view . She loves the Duke .
I 'm but a screen ; but I 'm content to suffer
When I remember how it serves the state
If he 's amused . And so I play the fool ,
And dance attendance on the little dancer .
She bade me bring her here this very night ,
Just to surprise the Duke .

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: His mother 's going out . There 's dancing .He hands METTERNICH a letter which he has taken out of a pocket-book .Read — From Fouché 's son .

lg.l: August the twentieth ,
Eighteen hundred and thirty —

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: Our Duke of Reichstadt to Napoleon Two .

lg.l: A list of partisans ?
Without destroying hope .
Ah , but my little Colonel serves me well
To keep these Frenchmen straight . When they forget
Their Metternich , and lean too much to the left ,
I let him show his nose out of his box , and — crack !—
When they come right , I pop him in again !

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: When can one see the springs work ?

div.stage: Enter the French ATTACHÉ .

lg.l: The Envoy
Of General Belliard . Welcome , sir .
The papers .
We accept in principle King Louis Philip ;
But do n't let 's have too much of ‘ 99 ,
Or we might crack a little egg-shell !
Sir ,
Are you alluding to Prince Francis Charles ?
The Duke of Reichstadt ? Oh , sir , as for me ,
I do n't admit his father reigned .
I do .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: So I 'll do nothing for the Duke . Yet —

lg.l: Yet , should you give too loose a reign to freedom ,
Permit yourself the slightest propaganda ,
Let Monsieur Royer-Collard come too often
And bare his bosom to your king ; in short ,
If your new kingdom 's too republican ,
We might — our temper 's not angelical —
We might remember Francis is our grandson .

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: Our lilies never shall turn red .

lg.l: And while
They keep their whiteness bees shall not approach them .

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: ‘ Tis feared in spite of you the Duke may hope .

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: Does n't he know that France has changed her king ?

lg.l: Yes ; but the detail he does not yet know
Is that his father 's flag , the tricolor ,
Is re-established . ‘ Twill be time enough —

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: He would be drunk with hope !

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: He 's not so strictly guarded here at Baden .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Oh , here there 's nought to fear . He 's with his mother .

lg.l: What spy could have such interest
In watching him ? For any plot would trouble
Her lovely calm .

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: Is not that calmness feigned ? She cannot have a thought but for her eaglet !

lg.l: My parrot !
Eh ?
Margharitina 's flown !
There , sir !
May I not seek it , Highness ?
No .
What 's wrong ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: We say , Your Majesty ; you called her Highness .

lg.l: But if we do n't allow the Emperor reigned
She cannot be addressed as Majesty
Except as Parma 's Duchess —

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: Then that was why she looked such daggers at me !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Question of protocols and of precedence .

lg.l: May the French Embassy from this day forward
Display the tricolor cockade ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: With a sigh .Of course , Since we 're agreed —Seeing the ATTACHÉ silently throw away the white cockade which was on his hat and replace it with a tricolor which he takes out of his pocket .Come , come ! You lose no time !

div.stage: Noise of harness-bells without .

lg.l: The guests of the Archduke .
The Meyendorffs , Lord Cowley , Thalberg —

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: Who has quickly come in R. at the sound of the bells , followed by TIBURTIUS .Meet them !

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Appearing on the threshold surrounded by a crowd of lords and ladies in elegant summer costumes . ( Light dresses and parasols ; large hats .Two little boys and a little girl dressed in the latest fashion . ] ‘ Tis but a villa ; not a palace .The room is crowded . She turns to a young man .Quick ! Thalberg , my Tarantelle !THALBERG sits at the piano and plays .To METTERNICH .Where is her Majesty , My lovely sister ?

sp.speaker: A LADY
sp.p: We looked in to fetch her .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER LADY
sp.p: We 're rushing through the valley on a coach . Sandor is driving .

lg.l: We must thrust the lava
Back in its crater !
Oh ! do hold your tongues
They will insist on talking of volcanoes .
Astrachan this winter .
Why , liberal opinions .
You hear him ?
Montenegro , sing to me
Under your breath , for me alone .

lg.stage: Whom THALBERG accompanies , sings very softly .
lg.l: Corazon —

div.stage: He continues , pianissimo .

lg.l: Ah , Gentz !
Some bon-bons , Gentz ?

div.stage: She gives him some .

lg.l: Perfume from Paris ?

div.stage: She takes out a little bottle of scent and gives it to him .

lg.l: Tear the label off !
“ The Reichstadt scent ” !
It smells of violets .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Snatches the bottle out of his hand and scrapes the label off with a pair of scissors he takes from the table .If the Duke came he 'd see that still at Paris —

lg.stage: Among the group at the back of the stage .
lg.l: The Hydra lifts its head —
Our husbands talk
Of Hydras !

sp.speaker: A LADY
sp.p: Yes ; Volcanoes first , then hydras . A MAID OF HONOR OF MARIA LOUISA .Followed by a servant bringing a tray with large glasses of iced coffee .Eis-Kaffee ?

lg.l: Recite some verses , Olga .
May we have
Something of Heine 's ?
The Grenadiers ?
Oh ! No !

lg.stage: Coming out of MARIA LOUISA 'S apartment .
lg.l: Her Majesty is on her way !
We 'll drive out to Krainerhütten ,
The ladies there can rest upon the green .
What are you reading yonder ?

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: Guess what they 're playing at the Vaudeville .

lg.l: Oh ?
“ Bonaparte . ” And the Variétés ?
“ Napoleon . ” The Luxembourg announces
“ Fourteen years of his life . ” At the Gymnase
They are reviving the “ Return from Russia . ”
What is the Gaiety to play this season ?
“ Napoleon 's Coachman ” and “ La Malmaison . ”
An unknown author 's done “ Saint Helena . ”
The Porte-Saint-Martin 's going to produce
“ Napoleon . ”

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: The Ambigu “ Murat ; ” the Cirque “ The Emperor . ”

lg.l: Yes , a fashion
Which will recur from time to time in France .

sp.speaker: A LADY
sp.p: Reading the paper over GENTZ 'S shoulder through a long-handled eye-glass .They want to bring his ashes home .

lg.l: The Phoenix
May rise again , but not the eagle .
What
An unknown quantity is France !
Oh , no ;
I 've gauged it .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: His words are graven in bronze .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Henry the Fifth . The others — Fashion .

lg.l: That 's a useful name
For calling glory by at times .
So long
As all the shouting 's only done in theatres ,
I think there 's no —
Long live Napoleon !
We must not lose our heads
Because a name is shouted .
It 's nothing .

sp.speaker: TIBURTIUS
sp.p: Two of them . I saw them .

lg.stage: Entering hurriedly and pale with fear from her room .
lg.l: Did you not hear the shout ? Oh , horrible !
It brought to mind — One day the people surged
About my coach in Parma with that cry !
It 's done to vex me !
Two of the Duke of Reichstadt 's regiment
Caught sight of him as he was riding homeward .
You know the deep ditch bordering the road ?
His Highness wished to leap it , but his horse
Shied , swerved , and backed . The Duke sat firm ,
And brought him to it again , and — over ! Then
The men , to applaud him , shouted . And that 's all .
Fetch one of them at once !

div.stage: An Austrian sergeant is brought in .

lg.l: A sergeant ! Now , my man , speak up . What meant
That shouting ?
No ; nor downstairs the corporal do n't know neither .
He shouted with me . It was good to see
The Prince so young and slender on his horse .
And then we 're proud of having for our Colonel
The son of —
He took the ditch
So cool and calm ! As pretty as a picture !
So then a sort of lump came in our throats ,
Pride and affection — I do n't know — we shouted
“ Long live —!
Enough , enough ! It 's just as easy
To shout “ Long live the Duke of Reichstadt , ” idiot !
“ Long live the Duke of Reichstadt ”
Is n't so easy as “ Long live — ”

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Be off . Do n't shout at all !

lg.stage: To the SERGEANT as he passes him to go out .
lg.l: You fool !

lg.stage: To the ladies who surround her .
lg.l: I 'm better , thank you .
Baron Dietrichstein , this is
My new companion-reader .
My son 's tutor .
And , by the way , I 've never thought of asking —
Do you read well ?
Take one of Franz 's books from yonder table ,
Open it anywhere .

lg.stage: Taking a book and reading the title .
lg.l: “ Andromache ” —
“ What is this fear , my lord , which strikes the heart ?
Has any Trojan hero slipped his chains ?
Their hate of Hector is not yet appeased :
They dread his son ! fit object of their dread !
A hapless child , who is not yet aware
His master 's Pyrrhus and his father Hector . ”
I —
“ Alas the day , when , prompted by his valor ,
To seek Achilles and to meet his doom ,
He called his son and wrapped him to his heart :
‘ Dear wife , ’ quoth he , and brushed away a tear ,
‘ I know not what the fates may have in store .
I leave my son to thee — ’ ”
H 'm — yes —
Let 's try
Some other volume . Take —

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: I know the author ! ‘ Twill not be so dull . He dined with us .To SCARAMPI .The Diplomat , you know .

lg.l: “ Never had hymns more strenuous and high
From seraph lips rung through the listening sky :
Courage ! Oh , fallen child of godlike race — ”
Forgive the interruption , Lamartine !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Delightful , mother . But , Mademoiselle , where did my entrance stop you ?

lg.l: “ Courage ! Oh , fallen child of godlike race ,
The glory of your birth is in your face !
All men who look on you — ”
Go , bid good morrow to your cousin .

div.stage: The children run up to the DUKE , who is seated , and surround him .

lg.l: Fie !
How pale he is !
You chose such awkward passages .
The book
Fell open by itself . I did not choose .
Books always open where most often read .
Archdukes upon his knees !

lg.stage: Leaning over the back of the DUKE 'S chair .
lg.l: I am delighted
To see you , Franz . I am your friend .

div.stage: She holds out her hand to him .

lg.l: I know it .
What do you think of him ? I say he 's like
A cherub who had secretly read “ Werther . ”
How nice your collar is !

sp.speaker: THE LITTLE GIRL
sp.p: What is your waistcoat made of ?

lg.l: Latest fashion :
In the third buttonhole . So glad you noticed .

div.stage: At this moment THERESA bursts into sobs .

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: Nothing . I do n't know . Forgive me . I 'm alone here — far from friends . Oh , it was silly !— suddenly —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: What 's this I trod on ? Why , a white cockade !

lg.l: Yours , no doubt , sir . Favor me : your hat .
lg.stage: The ATTACHÉ gives him his hat unwillingly . The DUKE sees the tricolor cockade .
lg.l: Ah !
I was not aware — but then — the flag ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Of a shade . See for yourself . Looked at in certain lights , I really think this is the more effective .He moves a few steps .

div.stage: His mother takes him by the arm and leads him to the butterfly-cases , which the DOCTOR , who has come back , has spread out .

sp.speaker: THE DOCTOR
sp.p: The plants it loves are umbelliferous .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: It seems to see me with its wings .

sp.speaker: THE DOCTOR
sp.p: Those eyes ? We call them lunulæ .

sp.speaker: THE DOCTOR
sp.p: Are you examining the spotted grey ?

lg.l: MARIA LOUISA .
We 'll wait . I count on the effect —
A sweetmeat ?
A flavor of verbena and of pear ,
And something else — wait — yes —
To feign an interest .
I 'm not so blind as Metternich .
A chocolate ?
I see a youth who suffers ,
Rather than live a favored prince 's life .
Your soul is still alive , but here at court
They 'll lull it fast asleep with love and music .
I had a soul once , like the rest of the world ;
But —! And I wither , decently obscene —
Till some day , in the cause of liberty ,
One of those rash young fools of the University
Amid my sweetmeats , perfumes , and dishonor
Slays me as Kotzebue was slain by Sand .
Yes , I 'm afraid — do try a sugared raisin —
That I shall perish at his hand .
His name
Is Frederick . ‘ Tis the youth you were yourself .
For now he 's risen again in you ; and since
He whispers in your ear like dull remorse ,
All 's over with you : he will show no mercy .

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: ‘ Tis true , my youth cuts like a knife within me . Ah , well I knew that gaze had not deceived me ! ‘ Tis that of one who ponders upon Empire .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I do not understand , sir , what you mean .

div.stage: He moves away .

lg.l: You 've had a chat with —?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: He 's in the hollow of my hand .

lg.l: Why did you weep ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Ah , no ! I know . But do not weep .

lg.l: I take my leave .

div.stage: He goes out with the ATTACHÉ .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: To MARIA LOUISA and DIETRICHSTEIN , who are turning over some papers on his table .Examining my work ?

sp.speaker: DIETRICHSTEIN
sp.p: It 's excellent . But why on purpose make mistakes in German ? Pure mischief !

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: Oh ! and at your age , mischief !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: How can I help it ? I am not an eagle .

sp.speaker: DIETRICHSTEIN
sp.p: You still make France a noun of feminine gender .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I never know what 's der or die or das .

sp.speaker: DIETRICHSTEIN
sp.p: In this case neuter is correct .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: But mean . I do n't much care about a neuter France .

lg.stage: To THALBERG , who is playing softly on the piano .
lg.l: My son detests all music .
Highness —
A pleasant word .
The English
Ambassador .
Where had you been just now
When you came galloping and out of breath ?
A wholesome , leafy nook . So gay !— At evening
Delightful . I should like to see you there .

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: Hastily to the AMBASSADOR , while the DUKE moves away .They call the village in the Helenenthal Saint Helena . A fashionable stroll .

lg.l: Ah , really ? I was almost wondering
Whether he meant it as a hit —?

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: Lifting his hands in amazement at LORD COWLEY 'S dulness .These English !

lg.l: Louisa ?
And you , Franz ?

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: He hates nature . He even gallops through Saint Helena .

div.stage: General leave-taking and gradual departure .

lg.l: I know a place for supper where the cider —
Good-bye ! Good-bye !
Do n't talk about the hydra !
Brother , good-bye !

div.stage: He goes out with BOMBELLES .

lg.stage: To the Maids of Honor , indicating THERESA .
lg.l: Show her her rooms .

div.stage: THERESA goes out accompanied by the Maids of Honor . MARIA LOUISA calls the Duke , who was going toward the garden .

lg.l: Franz !
Now I 'm going to amuse you .

div.stage: SCARAMPI carefully closes all the doors .

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: Hush ! They 've forbidden whatever comes from France — But I have ordered secretly from Paris , From the best houses — Oh ! my fop shall smile !— For you , a tailor ,Pointing to SCARAMPI .and for us , a fitter . I really think the notion —

lg.stage: Opening the door of MARIA LOUISA 'S apartment .
lg.l: Come in !

div.stage: Enter a young lady , dressed with the elegance of a milliner 's dummy , and carrying two great card-board dress-boxes , and a young man dressed like a fashion plate , who also carries two big boxes .

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.p: Coming down to the DUKE , while the young lady unpacks the dresses on a sofa at the back .If you will favor me , my Lord — I 've here some charming novelties . My clients Are good enough to trust my taste : I guide them . The neck-cloths first . A languid violet ; A serious brown . Bandannas are much worn . I note with pleasure that your Highness knows The delicate art of building up a stock . Here 's a check pattern makes an elegant knot . How does this waistcoat strike your Lordship 's fancy , Down which meander wreaths of blossoms ?

lg.l: Will these , I wonder , leave your Highness cold ?
Here 's doeskin . Here a genuine Scottish tweed .
Bottle-green riding-coat with narrow cuffs ;
Extremely gentlemanly . Here 's a waistcoat :
Six-buttoned . Three left open . Very tasty .
Now , what about this blue frock-coat ? We 've rubbed
The newness off artistically . Worn
With salt and pepper trousers , what a picture !
We 'll throw aside this heavy yellow stuff —
Can Hamlet wear the clumsy clouts of Falstaff ?—
We 'll pass to mantles , Prince . A splendid plaid ,
Demi-collar with simili-sleeves behind .
Eccentric ? Granted .— This , called the Roulière :
Sober , a large , Hidalgo-like effect ;
The very thing to woo a Doña Sol in .
Excellent workmanship ; a silver chain ; the collar
Of finest sable ; made in our own workshops ;
Simple , but what a cut ! The cut is everything .

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: The Duke is weary of your chatter .

lg.l: No .
He sets me dreaming . I 'm not used to it .
For when my tailor from Vienna comes
I never hear these bright , descriptive words ;
And so this wealth of curious adjectives
And all that seems to you mere vulgar chatter ,
Has moved me — stirred me . Let him be , dear mother .
We 'll look at ours . Shoulder of mutton sleeves ?
This cloth is called Marengo .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: So I should think . Marengo lasts forever .

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.p: One always needs a perfect-fitting coat .

lg.l: To suit your personal taste ?
O client , soar to fancy 's wildest heights !
Speak ! We will follow ! That 's our special line ;
Why , we are Monsieur Théophile Gautier 's tailors .
A Panama with muslin trimmings —
That 's not the sort of hat for everybody .
Of broadcloth . Yes
But now the texture ? Simple ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And then the color . What do you say to green ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: A little coat of green . With glimpses of the waistcoat ?

lg.l: Then , to give color when the wearer moves ,
The skirts are lined with scarlet .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Well , but about the waistcoat . How do you see the waistcoat ?

lg.l: And then I think
Knee breeches .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: No . I rather think I see them white cashmere .

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.p: Well , after all , white is the more becoming .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Yes ; something — nothing — merely little eagles .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Well ? What are you afraid of , sir ? And wherefore does your hand shake , master tailor ? What is there strange about the suit of clothes ? Do you no longer boast your skill to make it ?

sp.speaker: THE FITTER
sp.p: Coalscuttle bonnet neatly trimmed with poppies .

lg.l: Take home your latest fashions and your patterns ;
That little suit 's the only one I want .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: ‘ Tis well . Begone , and be discreet .

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.p: And I 'm empowered to take your order for it .

lg.l: A flowing cloak of China crape ;
Embroidered lining with enormous sleeves .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: A conspirator ? Now I no longer wonder you cite Shakespeare !

lg.l: The little coat of green holds in its thrall
Deputies , schools , a Peer , and a Field Marshal .

sp.speaker: THE FITTER
sp.p: Spencer of figured muslin . Satin skirt .

lg.l: Should I agree
I must beforehand — ay , and there 's the rub —
Consult my friend Prince Metternich .
You 'll trust us
When you are told our leader is your cousin
The Countess Camerata .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Ah , I know ! The daughter of Elisa Baciocchi .

lg.l: The strange , unarmored amazon , who bears
Her father 's likeness proudly in her face ,
Seeks dangers , rides unbroken horses , fences —

sp.speaker: THE FITTER
sp.p: A little sleeveless gown of lightest muslin .

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.p: And when you know it 's this Penthesilea —

sp.speaker: THE FITTER
sp.p: The collar 's only pinned , the shoulders basted —

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.p: Who heads the plot I spoke of —

lg.l: Turn round , your Highness ; glance at the young person
Who on her knees unpacks the clothes .
‘ Tis she !
Not long ago I met her in Vienna ,
Wrapped in a cloak . She swiftly kissed my hand
And fled , exclaiming , Have n't I the right
To greet the Emperor 's son who is my master ?
She is a Bonaparte ! We are alike !—
Ay , but her hair is dark ; not fair like mine .

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: We 'll try them on in there . Come , follow me . Only Parisians , Franz , know how to fit us .

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: Do n't you love Parisian taste ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: It 's very true they dress you well in Paris .

div.stage: MARIA LOUISA , SCARAMPI , and the FITTER go into MARIA LOUISA 'S apartment with the things they are to try on .

lg.l: I ? A nameless atom .
Weary of life in mean and paltry times ,
Of smoking pipes and dreaming of ideals .
Who am I ? How do I know ? That 's my trouble .
Am I at all ?— It 's very hard to “ be . ”
I study Victor Hugo ; spout his odes —
I tell you this , because this sort of thing
Is all contemporary youth . I spend
Extravagant fortunes in acquiring boredom .
I am an artist , Highness , and Young France .
Also I 'm carbonaro at your service .
And as I 'm always bored I wear red waistcoats ,
And that amuses me . At tying neck-cloths
I once was very good indeed . That 's why
They sent me here to-day to play the tailor .
I 'll add , to make the picture quite complete ,
That I 'm a liberal and a king-devourer .
My life and dagger are at your command .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I like you , sir , although your talk is crazy .

lg.l: You must not judge me by my whirling words ;
The itch of notoriety consumes me ,
But the disease beneath is very real ,
And makes me seek forgetfulness in danger .
Your soul
Heavy with foiled ambitions ?
Morbid enjoyment of our sufferings ,
And pride in showing off our pallid brows ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Contempt for those who live content ?

lg.l: In what mysterious volume
Has one so young learnt all the human heart ?
For that is what I feel .
Give me your hand !
For , as a sapling , friend , which is transplanted ,
Feels all the forest in its ignorant veins ,
And suffers when its distant mates are hurt ,
So I , who knew you not , here , all alone ,
Felt the distemper stirring in my blood
Which at this moment blights the youth of France .
Rather I think our malady is yours ,
For whence upon you falls this giant robe ?
Child , whom beforehand they have robbed of glory ,
Pale Prince , so pale against your sable suit ,
Why are you pale , my Prince ?
Well ! Feeble , feverish , dreaming of the past ,
Like you rebellious , what is left to do ?—
We 're all , to some extent , your father 's sons .
You are his soldiers ’ sons : that 's just as glorious .
And ‘ tis no less redoubtable a burden ;
But it emboldens me , for I can say
They 're but the sons of heroes of the empire :
They 'll be content to take the Emperor 's son !

lg.stage: Coming out of MARIA LOUISA 'S apartments .
lg.l: The scarf !— Oh , hush ! I 'm doing such a trade !

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: I only wish ‘ twere selling swords ! That silly baby-talk will be my death .

lg.l: The scarf !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: It seems this little hand can tame —

lg.l: I love
A fiery horse .
Indeed , I 'm looking for it everywhere .
Ready for anything for your Imperial Highness .
And my name
Is glorious .
Well ? Ca n't you find it ?

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: I must be off . Discuss our great design .With a cry , as if she had found what she was looking for .Ah ! here it is !

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: On the harp . You understand , it 's gathered up in folds —

div.stage: She goes into MARIA LOUISA 'S room .

lg.l: I do n't quite understand
Zealous Imperialism from a liberal —
You come to me
Rather a long way round —
All roads to-day
Lead to the King of Rome . My scarlet badge
I thought unfading —
Of Austerlitz ! Yes ! History makes us drunk .
The battles which no more are fought , are told .
The blood is vanished , but the glory gleams .
So that to-day there is no he but HE !
He never won such victories as now :
His soldiers perished , but his poets live .
In short the huckstering times ; the god
They exiled ; you , your touching fate , our weariness ,
And everything — I said —
You said as artist
‘ Twould be effective to be Bonapartist !
I listened well .
And you were charming as you spoke , but nothing .
No quiver of your voice , told me of France ;
You voiced a craze , a form of literature .
I 've carried out my mission clumsily ;
Could but the Countess yonder speak !
No use .
I love the bravery glowing in her eyes ,
But that 's not France : that is my Family !
When next you seek me , later , by and by ,
Let the call come through some untutored voice ,
Wherein rough accents of the people throb ;
Your Byronism is much too like myself .
You could not have persuaded me to-night —
I feel myself unready for the crown .

lg.stage: Coming out of MARIA LOUISA 'S apartment .
lg.l: Unready ? You ?
Do n't trouble ; I 'm just going .
And for the ball the white one , not the mauve .
Unready ? What do you want ?
A year of dreams ,
Of study .

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: The crown 's enough to ripen any brain .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The crown of light , shed by the midnight lamp .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I beg your pardon ? “ Chance ” ? Is this the tailor reappearing ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I will be honest in default of genius . I only ask three hundred wakeful nights .

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
sp.p: But this refusal will confirm the rumors .

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: They say you 've never really been of us .

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
sp.p: You are Young France : you 're called Old Austria .

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: They say your mind is being weakened .

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
sp.p: Yes ! They say you 're cheated , even in your studies .

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: They say you do not know your father 's history .

lg.l: Answer them thus —
Dear Count !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Ah ! for my history lesson ! Let him come .DIETRICHSTEIN goes out . The DUKE points to the clothes scattered about .Spend as much time as possible in packing , And try to get forgotten in your corner .Seeing DIETRICHSTEIN come in with BARON VON OBENAUS .Good-day , dear Baron .Carelessly to the YOUNG MAN and the COUNTESS , pointing to the screen .Finish over there .

div.stage: To OBENAUS .

lg.stage: Who has seated himself behind the table with DIETRICHSTEIN .
lg.l: Not at all , my Lord .

lg.stage: Who sits facing them , sharpening a pencil .
lg.l: I 'm all attention . Let me sharpen this
To note a date , or jot down an idea .

sp.speaker: OBENAUS
sp.p: We 'll take our work up where we last left off . Eighteen hundred and five , I think ?

lg.l: Did no event
Make that year memorable ?

lg.stage: Blowing the dust off the pencil .
lg.l: Why , eighteen hundred and five .
I beg your pardon ,
I thought you meant — h 'm — Destiny
Was cruel to the righteous cause . We 'll cast
Only a fleeting glance at hapless hours .
When the philosopher with pensive gaze —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And so in eighteen five , sir , nothing happened ?

lg.l: A great event , my Lord ! I had forgotten .
The restoration of the Calendar .
A little later , having challenged England ,
Spain —
And the Emperor ?
Indeed ?
He took great interest in Bavaria !
Your father 's wishes in the Pressburg Treaty ,
As far as that went , chimed with those of Austria .
The agreement
Which closed an era .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: So soon ? How quick ! Strange epoch ! Nothing happened in it !

lg.l: Yes .
For instance , take the House of the Braganzas :
The King —

sp.speaker: OBENAUS
sp.p: Nothing of any consequence till eighteen-eight . Yet let us note the Treaty of Tilsit .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Was nothing done but making treaties ?

lg.l: I 'll come to details
When we 've —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: What ? What happened ? Wo n't you tell me ?

lg.l: Well —
I hardly know — you 're in a merry humor —
You hardly know ? Then , gentlemen , I 'll tell you !
The sixth October , eighteen-five —
OBENAUS and DIETRICHSTEIN .
Eh ? What ?
When he was least expected , when Vienna ,
Watching the Eagle hover ere he swooped ,
Sighed with relief , The blow is aimed at London !
Having left Strassburg , crossed the Rhine at Kehl ,
The Emperor —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Yes ! and you know which ! Marches through Würtemberg , marches through Baden —

lg.l: Gives Austria a morning song ,
With drums by Soult , and trumpets by Murat !
At Wertingen and Augsburg leaves his Marshals
With here and there a victory to play with —
Pursues with wonderful manoeuvres .
Arrives at Ulm before he 's changed his boots .
Bids Ney take Elchingen , sits down and writes
A joyous , terrible , and calm despatch .
Prepares the assault :— the seventeenth October
Sees seven thousand Austrians disarmed ,
And eighteen generals at the hero 's feet ;
And then he starts again !
November
Finds him at Schönbrunn , sleeping in my bedroom .
He pursues ! his foes are in his hand !
One night he says “ To-morrow ! ” and to-morrow
Says , galloping along the bannered front —
A spot of grey among his brilliant staff —
“ Soldiers , we 'll finish with a thunderbolt ! ”
The army is an ocean . He awaits
The rising sun , and places with a smile
This risen sun athwart his history !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Terror and death ! Two Emperors beaten by one ! And twenty thousand prisoners !

sp.speaker: OBENAUS
sp.p: I beseech you ! People might hear !

lg.l: When the campaign was over —
The corpses floating on the freezing lake —
My Grandsire seeks my Father in his camp !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And so my Father grants my Grandsire peace !

lg.l: And the conquered banners
Distributed ! Eight to the town of Paris —

div.stage: The COUNTESS and the YOUNG MAN have gradually come out , pale and excited , from behind the screen . They listen to the DUKE with increasing emotion , and suddenly the boxes they are carrying slip from their hands .

lg.l: Oh !
Take your things !
Be off ! Be off !

div.stage: THE COUNTESS and THE YOUNG MAN go .

sp.speaker: DIETRICHSTEIN
sp.p: A little late , my Lord ! What will Prince Metternich —? These people here !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Moreover , that 's as far as I have got . My dear professor —

div.stage: He coughs .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I 've made good progress with my history ?

sp.speaker: DIETRICHSTEIN
sp.p: And yet no books come near you ! That I 'm sure of !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: You wo n't tell him ! The blame would fall on you .

lg.l: We 'd best keep still ,
And ask his mother to expostulate .
lg.stage: He knocks at MARIA LOUISA 'S door .
lg.l: The Duchess —?
She is ready . You may come .

div.stage: DIETRICHSTEIN goes in .

lg.l: Your course , Ad usum , sir , Delphini , sir ,
Is finished , sir !

sp.speaker: OBENAUS
sp.p: I can n't think how you learnt —!

div.stage: MARIA LOUISA comes in in great agitation , in a superb ball-dress , and with her cloak on . OBENAUS and DIETRICHSTEIN go out quietly .

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: Oh Heavens ! what is't again ? What must I hear ? Perhaps you will explain —

lg.l: My mother , look ,
The day is hushed , but for belated birds .
Oh , with what tenderness the gloaming fades !
The trees —

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: What , you ! Can you feel nature 's beauty ?

lg.l: Oh , mother ,
Inhale the perfume . All the forest floats
Into the chamber on its breath !
With every gust a branch is wafted in !
A fairer miracle than that which scared
Macbeth ; the forest is not walking only ,
Not like a mad thing walking ; lo ! on wings
The scented evening sets the forest flying !
At times .
Listen ! A waltz . An ordinary waltz ;
Yet distance gives it dignity . Who knows ?
Journeying through the woods the master haunted .
Under the cyclamen , among the bracken ,
It may have chanced upon Beethoven 's soul !
Yes ; when I choose .
I do not choose ! I hate the mystery
Of sounds ! And in a lovely sunset , feel
With dread some fair thing growing soft within me !

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: That fair thing in your heart , my son , is I !

lg.l: Then think a little ere you do me harm .
My father and Prince Metternich are so good !
When the decree , for instance , made you Count ,
I said , Not Count ; Duke at the least ; for Duke
Is something . And you 're Duke of Reichstadt .
Lord of Gross-Bohen , Buchtiehrad , Tirnowan ,
Schwaden , Kron-Porsitschan —

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: And then , the tact ! Your father 's name was never mentioned once !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Why not have called me “ Son of unknown Father ” ?

lg.l: With your estates and revenues you can be
The pleasantest and richest Prince of Austria .
First in precedence after the Archdukes ,
Some day you 'll marry with a fair Princess ,
Or an Archduchess , or perhaps a —
Ever
I see what once my childish eyes caught sight of :
His little throne , whose back was like a drum ,
And , made of gold , more splendid since Saint Helena .
Upon that back the simple little N ,
The letter which cries No to time !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Yes ! The N with which he branded Kings !

lg.l: The Kings
Whose blood runs through your mother 's veins and yours !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I do not need their blood ! What use to me ?

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: What ! Not proud to bear the blood of Charles the Fifth ?

lg.l: No ! for it courses in the veins of others !
But when I tell myself I bear in mine
A Corsican Lieutenant 's blood , I weep
To see the thin blue trickle at my wrist .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And the old blood can but harm the new . If I bear blood of Kings , let me be bled .

lg.l: What am I saying , after all ?
If ever I had yours long since I 've lost it .
His blood and yours have fought in me , and yours
Was put to flight , as usual , by the other .
Metternich , the fool ,
Thought to scrawl “ Duke of Reichstadt ” o'er my name .
But hold the paper up before the sun :
You 'll see “ Napoleon ” in the watermark !
You called me Duke of Reichstadt ? No !
But would you have my veritable name ?
‘ Tis what the people call me in the Prater
As they make way : The Little Bonaparte !
I am his son ! and no one 's son but his !
Ah , forgive me , mother , mother .
Go to the ball , forget my frenzied words .
You need not even trouble to repeat them
To Metternich , my mother .
Softly the waltz floats through the evening air ;
No , tell him nothing ; that will save you trouble .
Forget it all : you , who forget so quickly !
Think of Parma , of the Sala palace ,
And of your happy life . Is this a brow
To bear the shadow of an eagle 's wing ?
Ah ! but I love you more than you can think !
And take no heed of aught — not even — O gods !—
Of being faithful : I 'll be that for both .
Come , let me thrust you gently toward the ball ;
Good-night , The mosses must not wet your feet .
Your headdress is perfection .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The carriage waits . It 's fine . The night is clear . Good-night , Mamma ; enjoy yourself .MARIA LOUISA goes out . THE DUKE sinks in a chair before his table .Alas , Poor mother !His manner changes , and he draws books and papers toward him .Now ! to work !

div.stage: The wheels of a departing carriage are heard . The door at the back opens gently and GENTZ is seen introducing a woman wrapped in a cloak .

lg.l: She 's gone .
Prince !
Fanny ?
Farewell to dreams of Empire !
Franz !
Capital !

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Lovingly .My Franz !The door closes on GENTZ . FANNY quickly leaves the DUKE and speaks respectfully after making a profound curtsey .My Lord !

lg.stage: After looking round to assure himself GENTZ is gone .
lg.l: To work !

lg.stage: Swinging herself on to the table .
lg.l: I 've learnt whole chapters for to-day !
So , then , while Marshal Ney marched through the night ,
The Generals Gazan —
Gazan —
Kept up a lively cannonade ;
And at the earliest dawn the Imperial Guard —

div.stage: CURTAIN .
Illustration : decoration of three bees
Illustration : decoration of four Ns topped alternately by eagles or crowns .

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: The DUKE 'S cabinet at Schönbrunn . It is the famous Lacquered Chamber . At the back is a window opening on a balcony . In the distance , at the end of a beautiful avenue , the “ Gloriette , ” a Corinthian Portico . There are two doors on the left , and two on the right . Between these doors stand two large Louis XV . consoles . There is a large writing-table and other furniture in the styles of Louis XIV . and Louis XV . In the right-hand corner in front stands a large swinging mirror , with its back to the audience .
At the rise of the curtain SEDLINZKY ( the Prefect of the Police ) , the USHER , and a number of LACKEYS are discovered .

lg.l: And can you trust his personal attendants ?
Why , they are all professional policemen ,
As you , the Prefect of Police , must know .

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: Thank you . I fear the Duke may find me here .

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: Well , be keen and tactful . Let him not know he 's watched .

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: Not too much zeal ! I dread a zealous man . Do n't listen at his keyhole in a crowd .

sp.speaker: THE USHER
sp.p: I 've given that duty to a special man .

lg.l: I place him every evening in this chamber
Immediately his Highness seeks his room
No . As he wakes all night
He sleeps by daytime , while the Duke is out .
He 'll be here when the Duke is .
The papers —?

sp.speaker: Searched
sp.p: SEDLINZKY .Stooping under the table .The basket , too ?Seeing scraps of paper under the table , he hastily kneels to examine them .These scraps ?He tries to read .Perhaps a letter ?Urged by professional curiosity he creeps under the table .But from whom ?

div.stage: The DUKE enters in the uniform of an Austrian officer , followed by his Staff . The LACKEYS hurriedly range themselves .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Seeing SEDLINZKY 'S legs protruding from under the table ; very simply .Why , how are you , Sedlinzky ?

lg.l: Highness !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: An accident . Excuse me . Just come in .

lg.l: You knew me ? Yet I was —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Flat on your stomach ? Oh yes , I knew you .He sees the ARCHDUCHESS , who enters hurriedly carrying a large album .Ah , I feared as much ! They 've frightened you .

lg.l: The doctor ! But I am not ill !
Nothing . A choking . So I left parade .
I had been shouting .
lg.stage: To the DOCTOR , who is feeling his pulse .
lg.l: Doctor , you 're a nuisance !
lg.stage: To SEDLINZKY , who is sidling toward the door .
lg.l: ‘ Twas very kind of you to sort my papers .
You 're spoiling me . Indeed you are . You 've chosen
Even my lackeys from among your friends .
I should n't mind
If only they performed their duties better .
But I am villainously groomed . My stock
Rides up . In short , since this is your department ,
I wish you 'd black my boots a little better .

div.stage: A LACKEY brings a tray with refreshments , which the DOCTOR takes .

lg.stage: Anxious to help the DUKE from the tray .
lg.l: Franz —

lg.stage: To SEDLINZKY , who is again making for the door .
lg.l: You take nothing —?
We 'll manoeuvre
At early dawn the day after to-morrow ;
Assemble at Grosshofen .
I 'll not detain you , gentlemen . Good-day .

div.stage: FORESTI and the OFFICERS go out .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: To SEDLINZKY , taking a letter out of his pocket , and tossing it toward him .Dear Count , here is another you 've not read .

div.stage: SEDLINZKY and the DOCTOR go out .

lg.stage: Who came in a moment ago .
lg.l: I think you treat him rather harshly , Highness .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Is not the Duke at perfect liberty ?

sp.speaker: DIETRICHSTEIN
sp.p: Of course the Duke is not a prisoner , but —

lg.l: I like that “ but , ” I hope you feel its value !
Good Lord , I 'm not a prisoner , “ but ” — that 's all !
“ But ” — not a prisoner , “ but ” — that is the word ,
The formula ! A prisoner ? Oh , not a moment !
“ But ” there are always people at my heels .
A prisoner ? Not I ! You know I 'm not ;
“ But ” if I risk a stroll across the park
A hidden eye blossoms behind each leaf .
Of course not prisoner , “ but ” let anyone
Seek private speech with me , beneath each hedge
Up springs the mushroom ear . I 'm truly not
A prisoner , “ but ” when I ride , I feel
The delicate attention of an escort .
I 'm not the least bit in the world a prisoner ,
“ But ” I 'm the second to unseal my letters .
Not at all prisoner , “ but ” at night they post
A lackey at my door — look ! there he goes .
I , Duke of Reichstadt , prisoner ? Never ! never !
I , prisoner ? No ! I 'm not a prisoner — “ but ” —!

sp.speaker: DIETRICHSTEIN
sp.p: I love to see this mirth — so rare —

lg.l: Your Highness —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: — issimus ! That is my title . My particular title Kindly remember it another time !

lg.l: I leave you —

div.stage: He goes .

lg.l: Serenissimus ! how glorious !
What 's that ?
He lent it me
This morning , Franz .
It 's pretty .
You know Latin ,
What is this withered black thing ?

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Franz , there 's been something wrong with you of late .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: I find you nervous . What 's the matter ?

lg.l: Yes , but I know , your bosom-friend Prokesch ,
The confidant of hopes they think too vast ,
They 've sent him far away .
But in exchange
They give me Marshal Marmont as a friend .
Despised in France , he crawls to Austria
To gather praise for treason to my Father .
And a man like that is here to set
The son against the Father !— Oh !—

div.stage: Reading .

sp.speaker: Volubilis
sp.p: THE ARCHDUCHESS . Franz , when you promise do you keep your word ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: You 've been so good to me , I could not break it .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Besides , you liked my birthday present , Franz .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Ah , yes ! These relics from the archducal trophy !He takes the things he mentions , which are on a console between the doors on the right .A tinder box — a busby of the Guard — An ancient musket — No ! it is n't loaded ! And above all —

lg.l: That other thing —
I 've hidden it .
Well , promise then — your grandfather — you know
His kindness —

lg.stage: Picking up a paper which has fallen from the herbarium .
lg.l: What is this ? A sheet of paper ?
“ And if the students still persist in shouting .
Let them be crimped and sent on active service — ” .
You said — his kindness —

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Yes ; the Emperor loves you . His goodness —

lg.stage: Picking up another paper fallen from the herbarium .
lg.l: Here 's another .
“ As the mob
Resist you , cut them down . ”
His goodness —
He hates the ferment of the modern mind ,
But he 's an excellent old man .
Two-sided .
Flowers from whose leaves death-sentences are shed ,
Good Emperor Franz is like these specimens .
However , he 's beloved , he 's popular ,
I love him well .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: How he could help your cause !

lg.l: Promise you 'll never fly
Until you 've tried your utmost with him .
Yes ,
I promise that .
Oh , one has one 's little influence !
The astounding Prokesch they deprived you of —
I said and did so much — in short , he 's here .

div.stage: She strikes the ground with her parasol . The door opens and PROKESCH enters . The DUKE rushes to him . The ARCHDUCHESS goes out quickly .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Oh , they are ! They never tell , though .

lg.l: I 've tested them .
Uttered the most seditious sentiments ;
They 've never been repeated . Never .
I think the listener , paid by the police ,
Pockets the cash and stops his friendly ears .
Nothing . She 's forgotten me ;
Or else she 's been discovered — or , perhaps —
What folly not to have fled last year ! And yet
‘ Twas better ; now I 'm readier , but — forgotten .
It 's Chinese .
The hideous gilded birds ! The nightmare faces
Sneering with scorpion-smiles from every corner !
They lodge me in the famous lacquered chamber
So that my uniform may seem more white
Against the blackness of its glowing walls !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: They 've surrounded me with fools and knaves .

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: What have you done these last six months ?

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: The Gloriette looks well against the sky .

lg.l: Yes , while my heart is hungering for glory
I 've that diminutive : the Gloriette !

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: You 've all the park to ride in .

lg.l: Oh , the park
Is much too little .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The valley is too little for a gallop .

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: What do you want for galloping ?

lg.l: When from the glowing page of history
I lift dazed eyes , a forehead splashed with glory ,
Closing my Plutarch , leap with thee , O Cæsar ,
Upon a conquered land , with Alexander ,
With Hannibal , with thee , my Father —
What
Will your Highness please to wear to-night ?
There !
I 'm not going out .

div.stage: The LACKEY disappears .

lg.stage: Who has been turning over some books .
lg.l: They let you read ?
Oh , anything . The days are past when Fanny ,
That I might learn , learnt history by heart .
And , later , books were handed me in secret .
Every day a book .
Locked safe all night I read it . I was drunk !
When it was finished , to conceal my crime ,
I tossed it on the tester 's canopy ,
And there the heap grew , hidden in the darkness ;
I slept beneath a dome of history .
All day the heap lay quiet , but at night ,
When I was sleeping , it began to stir ,
And from the pages clamorous with battles .
The battles issued , stretching torpid wings ;
And laurels showered upon my slumbering eyes .
Austerlitz gleamed among my curtains , Jena
Glowed in the gilded tassels holding them
And on a sudden lapsed into my dream .
Till once , when Metternich was gravely telling
His version of my father 's history ,
Down comes my canopy crushed by the glory ;
A hundred volumes with their fluttering pages
Shouting one name !
No .
He smiled benignantly , and said , “ My Lord ,
Why keep your library so out of reach ? ”
And since that day I 've read whate'er I choose .
Yes ; but it 's French and blinded by its hate .
It says they 're poisoning me ; hints at Locusta
Who poisoned Claudius . If thy Prince is dying ,
Wherefore , O France , belittle his disease ?
It is no poisoned cup of melodrama
That kills the Duke of Reichstadt ! ‘ Tis his soul !
It is my soul ! it is my name !
That mighty name , which throbs with guns and bells ,
Clashes and thunders , ceaselessly reproaches
Against my languor with its bells and guns !
Silence your tocsins and your salvos ! Poison ?
What need of poison in the prison-house ?
I yearn to broaden history !— I am
A pallid visage watching at a window .
If I could only rid myself of doubt !
You know me well ! what do you think of me ?
Suppose I were what people say we are
And what we often are , we great men 's sons !
Metternich feeds this doubt with frequent hints :
He 's right ; it is his duty as an Austrian .
I shiver when he opes the bonbonnière
They call his wit , to find some honeyed venom .
You ! tell me honestly what is my worth ?
You know me ; can I be an Emperor ?
From this pale brow may God withhold the crown
Unless its pallor 's that of Bonaparte !
Answer me ! Must I despise myself ?
Speak out ! What am I ? Are my wits too dull ,
And are my wrists too feeble for the sceptre ?
What do you think of me ?
Prince , if all Princes
Struggled with half these torments , doubts , and fears
There would be none but admirable kings .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I thank you , Prokesch . Ah ! that word consoles me . To work , my friend !

div.stage: A LACKEY brings in a tray full of letters , places them on the table , and goes out .

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: Your mail has just arrived . A load of letters .

lg.l: Yes ; from women . These
Reach me unopened .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Yes ; That 's what it is to wear the fatal halo .He opens one letter after another ; reads the beginning and tears them up .“ I saw you in your box last night , how pale —! ” Destroyed ! “ Oh , that while brow ! ” Destroyed ! “ My Prince , I saw you riding in the Prater yesterday — ” Destroyed !

div.stage: The door opens gently and THERESA comes in .

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: Why do you always call me that ?

lg.l: ‘ Tis sweet ,
‘ Tis pure . It fits you .
Prince , I go to Parma
To-morrow with your mother .
And if my mother knows not what they stand for
Tell her .
Go , little Brooklet ,
Go on your innocent course .
Because the slumbering depths within your eyes ,
The murmur of your voice , so oft refreshed me .

div.stage: She goes .

lg.l: She loves me — and perhaps — but I must deal
In history and not romances ! Come !
To work , my friend ! We will resume our tactics .

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: I 'll plan an action : you shall criticise it .

lg.l: First give me yonder box upon the couch ,
The wooden box with all my wooden soldiers .
I 'll work the problem much more easily
Upon our little military chess-board .

lg.stage: After giving the box to the DUKE .
lg.l: You have to prove my plan is hazardous .

lg.stage: Putting his hand on the box .
lg.l: These are the soldiers of Napoleon 's son !
I 'm surrounded with such loving care ,
They even paint my soldiers — take them out —
They even paint my wooden soldiers Austrian !
Well ! hand me one . We will deploy our left .

div.stage: He takes the soldier PROKESCH hands him , and starts on seeing it .

lg.l: One of my father 's Grenadiers !
A Cuirassier !
lg.stage: He takes others out of the box .
lg.l: Light Infantry ! A scout !
They 're all become good Frenchmen ! Someone 's painted
Each of these little wooden combatants !
They 're French ! French ! French !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I tell you , someone 's carved and painted them !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And the artist was a soldier !

lg.l: Each coat of regal blue has seven buttons ,
The collars are correct , the linings faithful ,
The tunics , brandenburghs , and forage-caps ,
All 's there ! The painter never had to pause
To get the edgings and the facings right !
The lace is white , the flaps are triple-pointed !—
Oh , friend , whoe'er you are , with folded hands
I thank you , nameless soldier of my father !
I know not how you worked , nor whence you came .
How you found means , here , in our dismal gaol ,
To paint these little mannikins for me .
Who is the hero , little wooden army —
Only a hero would have been so childish —
Who is the hero who equipped you thus
That now you smile at me from all your trappings ?
Whose was the loving , microscopic brush
Which gave each tiny face its grim mustache ,
Stamped cannon cross-wise on each pouch , and gave
Each officer his bugle or grenade ?
Take them all out ! The table 's covered with them .
Here are the skirmishers , the fugle-men ,
The Infantry with shoulder-straps of green .
Take them all out ! They 're little conquerors !
Oh , Prokesch , look ! locked in that little box
Lay sleeping all the glorious Grande Armée !
Here are the Mamelukes — I recognize
The crimson breast-piece of the Polish Lancers .
Here are the Sappers with their purple breeches ,
And here at last , with different colored leggings .
The Grenadiers of the line with waving plumes
Who marched into the battle with white gaiters ;
The Conscripts here , with green and pear-shaped tufts .
Who marched to battle with their gaiters black .
Like a poor prisoner , who falls a-dreaming
Of vast and murmuring forests , with a tree
Fashioned of shavings , taken from a doll 's house ,
I build my Father 's Epic with these soldiers .
lg.stage: He moves away from the table .
lg.l: Why , yes , from here I cannot see at all
The little rounds of wood that keep them upright !
This army , Prokesch , when you move away
‘ Tis but the distance makes it look so small !
Place them in line for Wagram and for Eylau !
This naked yatagan shall be the water —
lg.stage: He takes a sword from the panoply .
lg.l: It is the Danube .
Essling ! Yonder 's Aspern .
Throw out a paper bridge across the steel .
Pass me a mounted Grenadier or two .
The “ Memorials . ”
Here stands Saint Cyr , here Molitor of Bellegarde
And on the bridge —

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Who has come in unperceived and is standing behind him .And on the bridge ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: So all the army 's French to-day , it seems ! Where are the Austrians ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Tut , tut — who daubed them over for you ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: ‘ Twas you . That 's how you spoil the toys we give you .

div.stage: METTERNICH rings — a LACKEY appears .

lg.l: Take these soldiers ; throw them all away .
I 'll send you new ones .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I 'll not have your new ones ! If I 'm a child , my toys shall be a giant 's !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: What gadfly — what Imperial bee has stung you ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: As irony is little to my liking —

lg.l: Silence , my Lord ! I 'll paint ‘ em over again .
Nothing . Just a fit of temper .
Forgive me .
I 've a friend ; I can be patient .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: I came to bring your friend —

lg.l: Yes ; Marshal
Marmont .
He 's among the few
I like to see about you —
I should hope so !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Why , let him come !METTERNICH goes out . The DUKE throws himself wildly on the couch .My father ! Glory ! The Eagles ! The Imperial throne ! The purple !Suddenly calm , he offers his hand to MARMONT , who enters with METTERNICH .Ah , Marshal Marmont ! How are you to-day ?

lg.l: Come , Prokesch , come and see how well
The Duke is lodged .

div.stage: He takes him by the arm and leads him off .

lg.l: You 've told me all you know
About my Father 's youth ?
We 'll sum it up
You 'd call him great ?
But ‘ twas you
Who helped —

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: We perfectly agree in our conclusions .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And I suppose he was , as we were saying —

lg.l: He was a General of some importance ;
Yet it were hardly fair to call him —
Now I 've learnt whatever you could teach me ,
Whatever memories of him you had ,
All that , in spite of you , was splendid in you .
I cast you off : a useless sponge !
Duke of Ragusa , you betrayed him ! You !
Ah , yes , I know , when you beheld your comrade
Climbing the throne you all said , “ Why not I ? ”
But you , whom even in the ranks he loved ,
And loved so well his men grew discontented ,
Created Marshal at the age of thirty —
You , traitor of Essonnes ,
The mob has found new uses for your name
And coined a verb “ Raguser , ” to betray !
Why do you stand there silent ? Answer me .
‘ Tis not alone Prince Francis Charles , it is
Napoleon the Second speaking to you .
They come — Prince Metternich — I know his voice .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Well ! you know what to do . Betray us twice !

lg.l: Do n't interrupt your chat . I 'm taking Prokesch
Across the park to see the Roman ruins
Where I propose to give a ball . I am
The last survivor of a crumbling world .
I like the idea of dancing over ruins .
Good-night .

div.stage: He goes out with PROKESCH .

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: My Lord , you see I held my peace .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: It only needed that you should raguse .

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: Oh , conjugate the verb ! I 'll take a seat .

lg.l: I will let you conjugate the verb
Because you were magnificent just now .
I have spoken evil of your Father
These fifteen years . I do so still ; ‘ tis true .
Can you not guess I seek to excuse myself ?
I never saw your Father after Elba —
If I had seen him I should have returned .
Others betrayed him , thinking to save France ;
But these beheld his face again , and fell
Under the spell , as I have fallen to-night .

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: I also have beheld his face .

lg.l: In that frown , and in that haughty gesture ;
The sparkling eye ! Insult me . I remain .
Almost you have atoned if that be true ,
Saved me from self-distrust which these exploit .
What ? With my gloomy brow and narrow chest —?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Dare I hope again ? Dare I forgive you ? Why did you betray him ?

lg.l: We were weary .
Can you not understand ? No peace in Europe .
It 's well to conquer , but one wants to live !
Berlin , Vienna , never , never Paris !
Beginning and beginning and beginning ,
Again , and yet again as in a nightmare ;
Forever and forever in the saddle
Till we were sick of it !

lg.stage: Having taken out the wooden soldiers and come back .
lg.l: What about us ?
Us , the men , the mean , the rank and file ?
Us , tramping broken , wounded , muddy , dying ,
Having no hope of duchies or endowments ,
Marching along and never getting further ,
Too simple and too ignorant to covet
The famous marshal 's baton in our knapsacks ?
What about us , who marched through every weather ,
Sweating but fearless , shivering without trembling ,
Kept on our feel by trumpet-calls , by fever ,
And by the songs we sang through conquered countries ?
Us upon whom for seventeen years — just think !—
The knapsack , sabre , turn-screw , flint , and gun ,
Beside the burden of an empty belly ,
Made the sweet weight of five and fifty pounds ?
Us , who wore bearskins in the burning tropics
And marched bareheaded through the snows of Russia ,
Who trotted casually from Spain to Austria ?
Us who , to free our travel-weary legs ,
Like carrots from the slough of miry roads ,
Often with both hands had to lug them out ?
Us , who , not having jujubes for our coughs ,
Took day-long foot-baths in the freezing Danube ?
Who just had leisure when some officer
Came riding up , and gayly cried “ To arms !
The enemy is on us ! Drive him back ! ”
To eat a slice of rook — and raw at that ,
Or quickly mix a delicate ice-cream
With melted snow and a dead horse 's blood ?
Us , who —
At night had little fear
Of bullets , but a holy dread of waking
Cannibals ; us —
Who marched and fought
Fasting , and only stopped —
To fight — and then stopped fighting , four to one ,
Only to march ; and stopped again to fight !
Marching and fighting , naked , starved , but merry —
Do n't you suppose we , too , were sick of it ?
Though we owed him precious little thanks ,
Nevertheless ‘ twas we whose hearts were true ,
While you were ambling at the King 's right hand .
In short , your Highness , in the great canteen ,
Where souls are fed on glory , he may find
His laurels are not worth our small potatoes .

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: Who is this Lackey with the veteran 's growl ?

lg.l: John Seraph Peter Flambeau , called Flambart —
“ The glowing coal ” — ex-sergeant grenadier .
Mamma from Picardy ; Papa a Breton .
Joined at fourteen , two Germinal , year Three .
Baptised , Marengo ; got my corporal 's stripes
The fifteenth Fructidor , year Twelve . Silk hose
And sergeant 's cane , steeped in my tears of joy .
July fourteenth , year Eighteen hundred and nine ,
At Schönbrunn , for the Guards were here to serve
The sacred person of your Majesty .
Sixteen years ’ service , seen sixteen campaigns ,
Fought Austerlitz , fought Eylau , Somo-Siera ,
Eckmühl , Essling , Wagram , Smolensk , and so forth .
Thirty-two feats of arms , a lot of wounds ,
And only fought for glory and dry bread .

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: Surely you will not listen to him thus ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: No , sir , I will not listen thus , but standing !

lg.l: For in the volume whose sublime
Chapters are headed with proud capitals
You are the titles and you catch the eye ;
But these — these are the thousand little letters —
You 're nought , without the black and humble army
That goes to make a page of history .
Oh , my brave Flambeau , painter of my soldiers ,
To think while you were near me all this month ,
I only looked upon you as a spy .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Oh , our acquaintance dates much further back !

lg.l: One Thursday in the garden of Saint Cloud
Marshal Duroc stood with a maid-in-waiting ,
Watching your Highness at his nurse 's breast —
Its whiteness , I remember , startled me .
Marshal Duroc exclaimed , “ Come here ! ” I came .
But there were lots of things to make me nervous :
The Imperial child , the gorgeous rosy sleeves
The Maid of honor wore , Duroc , the breast —
In short , the tuft was shivering on my bearskin ;
So much so that your Highness noticed it .
You gazed upon it pensively : what was it ?
And while you hailed it with a milky laugh
You seemed uncertain which to admire the more
About this moving scarlet miracle :
Its motion , or the fact that it was scarlet .
Suddenly , while I stooped , your little hands
Began lo pull the precious tuft about .
Seeing my plight , the Marshal cried severely ,
“ Do n't interfere ” — I did n't interfere ;
But having sunk upon my knees I heard
The nurse , the marshal , and the lady laughing .
And when I rose the grass was strewn with red :
As for my tuft , that was a beardless wire .
“ I 'll sign an order , ” said Duroc , “ for two . ”
Back to my quarters then I strutted radiant ;
“ You there ! hulloa ! ” exclaimed the Adjutant ,
“ Who 's plucked you ? ” And I cried : “ The King of Rome ! ”
And that is how one Thursday morn I met
Your Majesty . Your Highness has developed .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: No , not developed : that is why I grieve . My “ Majesty ” has shrivelled to my “ Highness . ”

lg.l: But since the Empire fell , what have you done ?
I think I 've acted like a decent beggar .
I know Fournier and Solignac . In May
Eighteen-sixteen Didier and Sarlovèze
Conspire and fail . I see the child Miard
Perish , and David the old man , and weep ;
They 'd have beheaded me , but I am missing .
Good . I come back to Paris with an alias ;
I smash a footstool on a royal guard
Because he 'd trodden on my favorite corn .
I take the chair at noisy drinking bouts ,
Spend thirty pence a month . I nurse a hope
That in the Var that Other still may land .
I swagger in a Bonapartist hat
And call whoever stares at me a vampire .
I fight some thirty duels . I conspire
At Béziers ; fail . They 'd have beheaded me ,
But I am missing . Good . I join at once
The plot at Lyons . All are seized . I fly .
They 'd have beheaded me , but I am missing .
So I come back to Paris , where , by chance ,
I find myself mixed up in the Bazaar plot .
Lefèvre-Desnouettes is in America .
I join him there . “ What 's up , my General ? ”
Says I . Says he , “ Come back . ” We start ; we 're wrecked .
My General 's drowned , but I know how to swim ;
And so I swim , bewailing Desnouettes .
Good . Very good . Sun — azure waves — and sea-mews .
A ship . They fish me up . I land in time
To be among the plotters of Saumur .
We fail again . They 'd have beheaded me ,
But I am missing . So I make for Greece ,
To rub the rust off , thrashing dirty Turks .
One morning in July I 'm back in France .
I see them heaping paving stones . I help .
I fight . At night the tricolor is hoisted .
Instead of the while banner of the King ,
But as I think there still is something lacking
To crown the point of that disloyal staff ;
You know — the golden thing that beats its wings .
I leave , to plot in the Romagna . Fail .
A relative of yours —
Camerata —
Makes me her fencing master —
In Tuscany .
So we conspire with singlestick and rapier .
Next there 's a post of danger vacant here ;
They give me forged credentials ; here I am .
I 'm here ; but every day I see the Countess ,
For I have found the cave your Highness dug
With your preceptor Colin in the garden
To play at little Robinson . All right !
I hide in it . I find it has two openings :
This in an ant-heap ; that , a bed of nettles .
I wait . Your cousin brings her sketch-book , and
There in the shadow of the Roman thingummies ,
She on her camp-stool , I amid the mud ,
She looking like an English tourist sketching ,
I whispering from my cavern like a prompter ,
We plan the means to make you Emperor .
And for such loyalty , so long maintained ,
What do you ask of me ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: As your Father used to when we 'd pleased him .

lg.l: I 'm waiting . Come . The thumb and index .
That 's not the way to pull an ear , my Lord !
You do n't know how : you 're much too gentlemanly .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Well , in a French Prince that 's but half a fault .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: But can you see I 'm French in these surroundings ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Yes , you do n't match . It 's rich ; it 's heavy .

lg.l: My brother 's an upholsterer .
He works in Paris for Fontaine and Percier —
They try to imitate us here ; but , Lord !
They 've got a curious kind of Louis-Quinze !
I 'm not an expert , but I 've got an eye .
Just look how finnicking this wood-work is .
lg.stage: He puts it down and looks at it .
lg.l: But then the tapestry ! What taste ! what mystery !
It sings . It laughs . It crushes all the room .
Why ? Do n't you know ? Why , these are Gobelins !
How plain it is that cunning craftsmen made them .
This taste , this elegance swears with the rest —
And you my Lord , were also made in France !
And on the Cross of Honor
Once more engrave a little Emperor .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Whom have they put there now ?

lg.l: Henry the Fourth —
Well , damn it all , it had to be a fighter !
But , basta ! How Napoleon must laugh
To wear King Henry 's mask upon his face !
Have n't you ever seen the cross ?
My Lord , it must be seen upon a breast .
Here on the cloth , a gout of ardent blood ,
Which fell , and falling turned to burnished gold
And to enamel with an edge of green ;
‘ Twas like a jewel pouring from a wound .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: It must have looked magnificent , my friend . Here on your bosom .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: What ! After all your modest heroism ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: One had to do far greater deeds to win it .

lg.l: The Little Corporal
Did n't bestow it ; so I had n't earned it .
Then I , who have no power , no throne , no title ,
I , who am but a memory in a phantom ,
That Duke of Reichstadt who with helpless grief
Can only wander under Austrian trees ,
Carving an N upon their mossy trunks ,
Wayfarer , only noticed when I cough ;
Who have no longer even the little piece
Of watered silk so scarlet in my cradle ;
I , on whose woes they vainly lavish stars ,
Who only wear two crosses , not the One !
I , exiled , prisoner , sick , who may not ride
Along the front of pompous regiments
Scattering stars among my heroes ; yet
I hope — I think — the son of such a father —
Into whose hands a firmament was given —
I think , in spite of shadows and dead days ,
A little of the star clings to my fingers :—
John Seraph Peter Flambeau , I adorn you !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Oh , this ribbon is not real .

lg.l: The real
Is that we weep in taking . I have wept .

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: Besides , it must be legalized in Paris .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: But how to get to Paris ?

lg.l: No more “ Alas . ” To-day 's the Ninth ,
And if you 'd like to be on the Pont-Neuf
The Thirtieth — you 'll be there if you like —
Come to the ball to-morrow given by Nepomuk .
Prince Metternich
Come . No more “ Alas ! ”

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: You utter dangerous secrets in my presence !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: You 'll not betray a plot in which you share .

lg.l: Yes , I 'm with you .
All the same
You did n't use much flattery to win me ;
You gave me quite a warm reception .
Yes ;
And won a warm reception for myself .
True , but then my failing
Is ever overdoing things a little .
I always add a trifle to my orders
And wear a rose-bud when I go to battle :
My little joke .
So if the Camerata
Cares to employ me —
I have lists
Carefully made , of all the malcontents ;
Maison , the French Ambassador , is my friend .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Compromises ! No ! I 'll not let Marmont consecrate himself !

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: When you are crowned , my Lord , I will obey you . Meanwhile I 'll go at once to General Maison .

div.stage: MARMONT goes out .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: That venerable rascal 's in the right .

lg.l: So be it , then ! I 'll come . But where 's the proof
That France still feels herself my Father 's widow ?
Oh , Flambeau , time has passed ; the ancient love
These worthy people bore us must have died .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Their love of you , my Lord ? Why that 's immortal !

div.stage: He takes from about his person the various articles mentioned in the following scene .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Just look and see what 's on ‘ em !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Worn by quite a decent class .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Will you take a pinch of snuff ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: On the box a little curly head .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: And what about this handkerchief ? Eh ! Not so bad , the little King of Rome ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Colored print to paste upon your walls .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Yes , and caracolling . How d'you like this pipe ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: You cannot say they have n't drawn you handsome !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: A cockade , to tease the government .

lg.l: Still you . Look here , what words are ground
Upon this tumbler ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Of course you can n't get on without a plate —

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: A knife , a napkin-ring , an egg-cup . They 've made you look so happy on the egg-cup ! The table 's laid , my Lord : my Lord is served !

lg.l: Flambeau —
On everything . Here 's a cravat
In which you 're woven riding in the clouds ;
And playing cards of which you 're Ace of Spades —

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: What , weeping ? Take this handkerchief And dry your eyes upon the King of Rome !He kneels by the DUKE 'S side and wipes his eyes with the handkerchief .I bid you strike the iron while it 's hot : You 've got the people and you 've got the Marshals , The King , the King himself , is only King On one condition : that he 's Bonapartist . Vainly the Gallic cockerel spreads his wings That , from a distance , he may seem an eagle . We Frenchmen cannot breathe inglorious air ; The crown must slip from off a pear-shaped head . The youth of France will rally to your side Merrily shouting songs of Béranger — The street has shuddered and the pavement trembled , And Schönbrunn 's not so pretty as Versailles !

lg.l: I will accept .
Ha !
In the Court of honor
The trumpets of the Guard . The Emperor
Is coming home .
My grandfather ! My promise !
No ; before accepting —
Listen !
I must make one attempt with him ; but if
When you are here on guard to-night , you see
Something — that you 're not used to seeing here —
It is a signal ! I will fly .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Latude ! What will the signal be ?

div.stage: An officer of the Noble Guard enters .

lg.l: The beggars ! Are n't they gorgeous swells !
As the Emperor passed , they came and said ,
“ O Sire , this is the one day in the week
Whereon your Majesty receives his subjects ;
Many have come from far — ” “ I 'd thought of it , ”
Replied the Emperor , smiling ; “ and I hope
To see them . I 'm at Schönbrunn as a grandfather ,
I shall be with the Duke from five to six :
Let all my children be beside my grandson . ”
May they come up ?

div.stage: The OFFICER goes out .

lg.l: Now quickly make a bundle of these treasures .
I 'll look at them at leisure in my room .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: I make the bundle in the handkerchief . But tell me what the signal is to be .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Oh , never fear ! you will not fail to know it . But — do you hear them ? That 's the Austrian Hymn .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: My word ! It is n't worth the Marseillaise !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The Marseillaise — well ? have you tied the ends ? My father used to say it wore mustachios .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Their blessed national hymn has scented whiskers .

lg.l: It would n't be bad fun to enter France ,
Thus , with my bundle on my back , on foot .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: How cheerful and how funny you can be ! This is the first time I have seen you so .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: What ? Rather young and merry ? Thank you , Flambeau .

div.stage: CURTAIN .
Illustration : decoration of two eagles with an orb between
Illustration : decoration of an eagle with wings spread wide and a crown above its head

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

stage.stage: Scene : The same as in the previous act .
A miscellaneous crowd of men , women and children are discovered on the rising of the curtain . They are being placed in order by an OFFICER .

sp.speaker: THE OFFICER
