sp.p: Line up . Be quiet . Boy , behave yourself . The Emperor enters here ; so leave a passage . You , giant Highlander , do n't scrape your feet .

lg.l: Yes ; and he 'll take your papers .
Hold your petitions so that he can see them .
No tedious twaddle — Ah !— and you 're forbidden
To kneel when he comes in .
Forbidden or not ,
That wo n't prevent us —

div.stage: The EMPEROR enters quite simply , without being announced . All the people , in spite of the warning , fall on their knees .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Rise , my children , rise .He passes from one to the other , taking their papers . To a WOMAN .Your pension 's doubled .

lg.l: What ? What ? A team
Of oxen ? That 's expensive !— Granted .
What , you ? All well
At home ?

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Why , do n't you see , the wind has killed my chickens .

lg.l: Come
And yodle to the Court at Baden .
Out yonder
My home is , on the mountains , in the skies .
I want to be a cabman in Vienna .
Well , so you shall .
A wealthy husbandman
Begs Franz to give him back his daughter 's love
Which a Bohemian glass-blower has stolen .
You 'll wed your child to her Bohemian lover .

sp.speaker: THE HUSBANDMAN
sp.p: Johannes Schmoll . I kiss your hands .

lg.l: “ A shepherd of the Tyrol ,
A friendless orphan , robbed of all his land ,
Driven from his homestead by his father 's foes ,
Yearns for his native woods and skies ” — how touching !—
“ And his paternal meadow . ” ‘ Tis restored .

sp.speaker: THE CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: What is the shepherd 's name , who asks for help ?

sp.speaker: THE SHEPHERD
sp.p: The Duke of Reichstadt ! And the meadow 's France !

lg.l: Begone !
What 's this ?
It seems if I were only
A mountain shepherd or a forester ,
With nothing to attract your notice , Sire ,
Save a cock 's feather in my huntsman 's hat ,
You would have drawn me to your melting heart .
Ah , now I know why all your subjects ,
All those who are unhappy , call themselves
Your sons as much as we ; but is it just ,
Sire , is it just , that I , when I 'm unhappy ,
Have less of kinship than the least of these ?
But why just now — for I must scold you , sir —
When I was busy with these wretched people —
Why come to me just now , and not in private ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I wished to find you when your heart was open .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: My heart — my heart !— You 're somewhat over-bold !

lg.l: I know that you can do the thing I ask ,
That I am wretched almost past endurance ,
And that you are my Grandfather — that 's all .
But there is Europe — England — above all ,
There 's Metternich .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: You do n't know half the difficulties .

lg.l: But
I am the grandson of your Majesty .
Sire , in whom alone I place my trust ,
Be Grandfather a little while !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Just for a moment drop the Emperor .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Ah , what a coaxing way you always had .

lg.l: You know I cannot bear you when you look
Like the great portrait hanging in the throne-room ,
With the ermine cloak and Golden Fleece upon you ;
But here , like this , I like you very much .
With the dear silver of your floating hair ,
Your kindly eyes , your simple coat and waistcoat ;
For now you 're just a dear old gentleman ,
By whom a grandchild might be petted .
Are you not bored to see the heavy jowls
Of Louis-Philip on the coins of France ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Do you adore these podgy Bourbons ?

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: You are not like your cousins the Archdukes .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Where did you learn your saucy tricks ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I learnt them playing in the Tuileries .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Ah , you come back to that ?

lg.l: I remember
A man who pressed me hard against a star ,
And as he pressed I felt with tears of fright
The diamond star was stamped upon my heart :
Sire , it has stayed there !

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Do I blame you for it ?

lg.l: Yes , let the goodness of your nature speak !
When I was small you loved me , did you not ?
You loved to have me with you at your meals ,
And so we used to dine together —
My hair was long , and I was Prince of Parma ;
And when they punished me you let me off .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Do you remember how you hated ponies ?

lg.l: One day they showed me one as white as snow ;
I stamped with fury in the riding-school .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: You thought a pony was a deadly insult .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I cried with rage : I want a great , big horse !

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: And now you want another great , big horse !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And how I used to beat my German nurses .

lg.l: And how with Colin you would calmly dig
Enormous holes about my park —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And I used to hide . I had a gun , three hatchets and a bow .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Then you stood sentinel before my door .

lg.l: And ladies , coming late ,
Found this excuse quite natural :— “ Oh , Sire ,
We only stopped to kiss the sentinel ! ”
Is it true the King
Would simply disappear if I appeared ?
Yes ; if you appeared alone ,
Without a drum , upon the bridge at Strassburg ,
The King would vanish .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: I should have held my tongue .

lg.l: Besides , the climate of Vienna 's bad :
I 'm ordered Paris —
For my cough .
If I 'm to spend a season there , of course
I can n't stop anywhere but at the Louvre .
They 've often begged us
To wink at your escaping —
Do n't think ! Do n't think those horrid second thoughts !
Consult your feelings only , and your heart ,
‘ Twould be so pretty if an Emperor once
Upset all history to spoil his grandson .
And then it 's something , something rather fine ,
If you can just remark quite innocently ,
You know : “ My Grandson , Emperor of the French . ”

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And you 'll say it ! Say you 'll say it !

div.stage: They salute each other as equals .
A door opens .
Enter METTERNICH .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: It is my will this child shall reign .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Delightful . I 'll tell your partisans at once .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: What should you fear ? Am I not master here ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Whom will you send me as Ambassador ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And you 'll visit me in state ?

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Yes , very likely ; when the chambers rise .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: We 'll only ask some trifling guarantees .

lg.l: First
We 'll come to terms on trivial points of detail :
Certain seditious groups should be dissolved :
Our neighbors must not harbor thunderbolts .
Ah — then we 're very weary
Of hearing of the Heroes of July .
Now the imperialists and radicals
Are linked : we 'll cut the link ; we cannot favor
The dangerous modern spirit . We 'll expel
Lammenais .
And Chateaubriand . Ah —
We 'll also put a muzzle on the press .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Ah — we must have free hand in Italy . Ah — not so much excitement about Poland .

lg.l: Well , we shall have to solve
The question of the names . You know , the names
Of battles , Sire , which you — well — did not win :
The Marshals must not wear them .
Forgive me ; but they must not think
They 're lords of Austrian places ; and you cannot
Approve their way of carrying off to France
Our villages by means of upstart titles .
Yet you and I were in each other 's arms !
And have you nothing further to demand ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Yes ; the suppression of the Tricolor .

lg.l: Your Excellency wishes me to wash
The banner based in blood and crowned with heaven —
For it was dipped in horrors that bear fruit ,
And it was bathed in universal hopes !—
Your Excellency asks me to efface
That gleam of heaven and that stain of blood ,
And , having nothing but a blank sheet left ,
To make a shroud for Freedom out of that !
Upon my father 's side
I am related closely , Sire , to Freedom .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Yes , the Duke 's grandsire was the eighteenth Brumaire !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Yes , and the Revolution was my granddam !

lg.l: The Emperor a republican !
Utopia !— Play the Marseillaise in A
On trumpets , while the sentimental flute
Sighs “ God preserve the Empire ” in E flat .
The two go very well together , sir ,
And make a tune that frightens Kings away !

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: This to my face ? How dare you , sir ? How dare you ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Ah , now I know what is expected of me !

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: What does it mean ? What is the matter with him ?

lg.l: I am to be an Austrian Archduke
On a French throne !

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: What has he read or seen ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I have seen egg-cups , handkerchiefs , and pipes !

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: He 's mad ! The words he utters are a madman 's !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Mad to have thought you 'd help me to my own .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: ‘ Tis you alone obstruct your going home .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Yes , in a gig instead of on a gun !

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: You shall not go at all !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: For all your cages I am still the Eaglet !

lg.l: The eagle on my flag has many eaglets :
You 're one of them : that 's all .
Oh , gloomy eagle !
Sad , double-headed fowl , with heavy eye :
Eagle of Austria , cruel bird of night !
A glorious eagle of the dawn has passed
Athwart thine eyrie , and with ruffled feathers ,
Raging and terror-stricken , thou beholdest
One of thine eaglets sprouting golden plumage !

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: My heart was softening : I regret my tears . These books and weapons shall be taken from you . Dietrichstein !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: He is not in the palace .

lg.l: Poor , morbid child , we will suppress whatever
Too much reminds you who your father was .
Then you must root up every violet ,
Drive every single bee out of your park !
I 'll dismiss them all :
Otto , Fritz , Hermann , Albrecht —
Close the shutters ,
Lest yonder star remind me of my father 's .
And as for Dietrichstein , I 'll sign at once
New regulations —

div.stage: To METTERNICH .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: My inkstand 's on the table ; you may use it .

lg.l: The Minerva 's head ,
In bronze and marble .
Then take the other , made of burnished gold ,
On yonder console —
Sire ,
Those which my father left me .
Yes ! in his testament ! And there , the pistols ,
Four pistols of Versailles . Take them away .

lg.stage: Bringing his fist down on the table .
lg.l: What 's this ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: You must not hit the table , Sire ! Now you 've knocked down the sword he wore as Consul !

lg.l: Are before my eyes !
“ They are to be surrendered to my son
When he has reached sixteen . ” Despite the crime
Which holds them back , they 're mine : I have their soul !
The soul of every cross , of every jewel ,
And all is here : the three mahogany caskets ,
And all the snuff-boxes , and all the spurs ,
The golden garter-buckles and the gorgets ,
I 've all ! The iron sword , the enamelled sword ,
The sword in which a never-setting sun
Has left its fires imprisoned , so that none
May dare to draw it lest the sun leap forth ;
I have the sword-belts also , all the six !
“ To be surrendered to my son
When he has reached sixteen . ” Oh , Father , sleep .
For I have all ; even your uniforms .
Oh , yes ! To you my uniform looks white —
Well , it 's not true — it 's false — I am pretending !
Father , behold , it 's blue and red , behold !
Colonel ? Not so ! Lieutenant in your Guard !
By the device your soldiers bore I know it ,
Father , who gave me victories for sisters !
‘ Twas not in vain you wished me to possess
The alarm-clock of King Frederick of Prussia ,
Which you magnificently stole from Potsdam ,
For here it is ! ‘ Tis ticking in my brain !
It is the clock which wakes me every morning ,
Drives me exhausted by my midnight toil
Back to my narrow table , to my toil ,
To be more fit by night-fall for the throne !
The throne ! the throne ! Oh , never hope again
That you may reign in France , you — Upstart 's son ,
Because our nobler blood has made you look
Rather more kingly than your father was .
Forgive me , but at Dresden , you remember ,
You all appeared like lackeys of my father .
He had but to ask
And Emperors gave their daughters to this soldier .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Perhaps . I cannot say . Mine is a widow .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Pity I 'm here as living evidence !

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Have you forgotten how we loved each other ?

lg.l: No ! No ! My birth is proof that you were beaten !
No ! you can only hate me ; for I am
Wagram personified before your eyes !
Out of my sight ! Begone !
The child I loved !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Well , Sire , is he to have an empire ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Do you perceive what I have saved you from ?

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: Ah ! did you hear the monstrous things he said ?

lg.l: For his own sake ; yes ,
METTERNICH .
For the world 's peace and yours .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: I 'll come and speak to him to-night .

lg.l: What grief
He gives me !
This scene
Must never be repeated .

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.p: It has hurt me . Unhappy child !

lg.l: Come , Sire .
The child —

div.stage: His voice dies away .
The DUKE opens his door very gently , sees they are gone , listens a moment , then enters quickly and places one of Napoleon 's little hats on the table .
He returns to his room .
FLAMBEAU enters .

lg.l: ‘ Tis time . Well , signal ? Are you here ?— Perhaps .
“ Flambeau , ” he said , “ you cannot fail to find it . ”
Now , is it high or low , or black or white ?
Or great or small ?
The Emperor 's —! Small and great !
Oh , but the Countess watches in the park ,
And if the signal 's here I am to signal :
No ! This wo n't do . A white flag makes her ill .

div.stage: A servant enters with a reading-lamp , which he carries toward the DUKE 'S room .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Leaping upon him and seizing the lamp .You dolt ! It 's leaking ! It must have fresh air !He takes it out on the balcony .You wave it three times so : arrange the wick ;He does as he says and gives the lamp back to the SERVANT .That 's it . See that ?

div.stage: He carries the lamp into the DUKE 'S room .
SEDLINZKY enters .
He goes out .

lg.l: Locked !
Take the key out .
None but the Emperor has the key . Be careful —
Watch .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: As I always do .He bends over the key-holes and arranges them carefully .And for the night I 'll close the eyelids of the key-holes softly .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Good-night !He throws off his livery coat . Puts on the busby , which is standing on the console , and shoulders the musket . He is now in the full accoutrement of a Grenadier of the Guards .And thus , Suddenly upright , thin , unliveried , Locked in till dawn , and safe against surprise , Glowering with grizzled brows beneath his busby , Straight in his ancient uniform , his gun Firm in his arm , his hand on his right nipple , The fixed and regulation attitude , Standing thus every night before your threshold , Giving himself a password full of pride , Pleased with a deed that 's grave , and yet a jest , A Grenadier at Schönbrunn stands on guard About the son as once about the Father . ‘ Tis the last time ! You 'll never hear of it . ‘ Tis for myself . A private luxury . I must be mad to do a thing like this For no one 's eye , but just to say “ By Jove , That 's rather good ! ” At Schönbrunn ! In their teeth ! But I 'm delighted !— I 'm content !He hears the noise of a key in the door .I 'm damned !The door opens gently .Who can have got the key ?

div.stage: He retires into the shadow by the DUKE 'S door .
METTERNICH enters , carrying a large candelabrum .

lg.l: No , no ! This scene
Must never be repeated .
Yes , I will speak to-night . We are alone .
lg.stage: As he puts down the candelabrum he sees the hat .
lg.l: What 's this ? I never knew he had one like —
Ah ! the Archduchess must have sent him this ;
So there thou art , thou legendary hat !
‘ Tis many years — Good day !— What sayst thou ? What ?
No , from thy little sable pyramid
Twelve years of splendor gaze on me in vain ,
I do not fear thee now .
The leathern tag
With which he constantly could take thee off ,
And so win cheers yet leave thy shape unharmed .
With thee he fanned himself after each victory ;
Thou couldst not fall from his unheeding fingers ,
But straight a king would stoop to pick thee up .
To-day , my friend , thou art a reach-me-down ,
And if I tossed thee through the casement yonder
Where wouldst thou end thy days ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: The famous little hat — how very ugly ! They called it little — is it really little ? No ; it is big ; enormous ; it 's the hat A little man puts on to increase his inches . For ‘ twas a hatter set the legend going : The real Napoleon , after all , was Poupart . Ah , never think my hatred of thee slumbers ! ‘ Twas for thy shape 's sake first I hated thee , Thou vampire-bat of bloody battle-fields , Hat that seemed fashioned out of raven 's wings . I hated thee for pitilessly soaring Above the fields which witnessed our defeats , Half-circle , seeming on the ruddy sky The orb half-risen of some sable sun ! And for thy crown wherein the devil lurks , Thou juggler 's hat , laid with a sudden hand Upon a throne , an army , or a nation — When thou wert lifted all had disappeared . I hated thee for the salutes I gave thee , For thy simplicity — mere affectation — Thy insolent joy , thou piece of common beaver Amid the glittering diadems of gold ; For staying firmly on his haughty head When I sought flattering epithets to please thee . Conqueror , new , acclaimed , I hated thee ! I hate thee now , old , conquered and betrayed ! I hate thee for thy haughty shadow , cast Forever on the wall of history ; I hate thee for thy Jacobin cockade , Staring upon me like a bloodshot eye ; For all the murmurs sounding in thy shell , That huge black shell the waves have left behind Wherein the shuddering listener may hear The rumor of a nation on the march . I hate thee for the pride of France , whose bounds Thou hast enlarged until she scorns the world ; For Béranger I hate thee , and Raffet , For all the songs and all the pasquinades , And for the halo of Saint Helena . I hate thee , hate thee . I shall not be happy Until thy clumsy triangle of cloth , Despoiled of its traditions , is again What it should ne'er have ceased to be in France — The headgear of a village constable . I hate — but suddenly — how strange !— the present Sometimes with impish glee will ape the past !— Seeing thy well-known shape before me thus Carries my mind back to a distant day , For it was here he always put thee down When twenty years ago he sojourned here . This room was then the ante-chamber ; here , Waiting till graciously he showed himself , Dukes , Princes , Magyars , huddling in a corner , Fixed from afar their humbled eyes upon thee , Like lions , dreading with a helpless fury The tamer 's hat forgotten in the cage . ‘ Twas thus he placed thee , and here lay , as now , Weapons and papers . One might say ‘ twas he Had tossed thee carelessly upon the map , That this were still his home , this Bonaparte ! And that by turning , on the threshold — there — I should behold the Grenadier on —He starts on seeing FLAMBEAU standing rigid before the DUKE 'S door ; he rubs his eyes .Ha ! No ! no ! I 'm feverish ; my tête-à-tête With the old hat plays havoc with my nerves !He looks and draws near . FLAMBEAU does not move .Or have the moonbeams conjured up a spectre ? What is it , then ? Let 's see — let 's see — let 's see !He strides furiously toward FLAMBEAU .Who are you , fellow ?

lg.l: Who goes there ?
The devil !
Pass , devil .

lg.stage: With a forced laugh , coming toward him again .
lg.l: Yes ,— a very clever jest ,
But —
Who goes there ?
But —

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: I 'm the Austrian Chancellor ! I am all-powerful ! I 'm —

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: I want to see the Duke of Reichstadt !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: What 's Reichstadt ? Never heard of Reichstadt ! Auerstadt , Elchingen , they 're dukes I know . Reichstadt 's no duke . There 's been no victory there .

lg.l: I should rather think so !
Thanks to our new success we 're quartered here ;
And here we 're getting ready at our leisure
To give the world another drubbing ! See ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: What 's that you say ? A new success ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: This is July the ninth in Eighteen —

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Who are you ? Where d'you spring from ? Why are n't you snug in bed ? It 's very fishy —

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Who let this braggart pass ? The Mameluke ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: You here in the ante-room at night !

lg.l: You calmly cross the Rosa chamber
Unchallenged by the sentinel on guard !
When you ventured through the small rotunda ,
Was there no yatagan to shave your cheek ?
Were there no sergeants in the white saloon
Brewing their punch upon the golden stove ?
No bristling veterans in the china-room ?
And in the galleries ? The Grenadiers
Saw you come strolling as a matter-of-course ?
A man may cross the oval cabinet
And not be turned to mince-meat by Duroc ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Is the bulldog turned to lapdog ?

lg.l: So the palace is an inn ?
And when you 'd managed all the sentinels ,
Where were the rest ? The porter ? Gone to bed ?
The valet ? Absent ? And the secretary ?
Where was he hidden ? In his own portfolio ?
Instead of being after you ,
No doubt the Aide-de-Camp was after women !
And the Moor was saying prayers to Allah ?
At any rate it 's lucky I was here .
What discipline ! If he looks into this
I 'll bet my head he 'll let the beggars know !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Ah ! do n't stir ! You 'll wake him ! He 's sleeping on his little bed of laurels .

lg.l: Was never such a dream ! ‘ Twill make an epic !
lg.stage: His hand touches the flame of one of the candles .
lg.l: Well , but this candle —

lg.stage: Feeling the point of FLAMBEAU 'S bayonet .
lg.l: This weapon —
Of water — what ?
The Emperor stirred .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Oh , my stars ! Now you turn whiter than a bugler 's horse !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: It is the Duke of Reichstadt ! I 'm not scared ! It is the Duke ! I 'm sure of it !

div.stage: The DUKE enters , with the reading lamp in his hand .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Aha ! Tis you ! ‘ Tis you ! It is your Highness ! Ah , but how glad I am !

lg.l: Why are you glad ?
The joke was played so well , I really thought
Another might come out !

lg.stage: As if waking from a dream .
lg.l: Faith , so did I !
What 's this ?
Help !
No !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Bah !Aside to the DUKE , while METTERNICH rings again .I will seek my cavern .

div.stage: FLAMBEAU goes out by the window .

lg.l: If he 'd only break
His neck — He 's singing !
Hush !

div.stage: A shot is heard .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: With what ease he finds his way about .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: He knows it ; he has been here once before .

lg.stage: To the LACKEYS who show themselves at the door .
lg.l: Too late . Begone . I do not need your help .

div.stage: The LACKEYS disappear .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And not a word of this to the police !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: I never raise a laugh against myself . What 's the importance of a veteran 's joke ? You 're not Napoleon ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: You have his hat , perhaps , but not his head !

lg.l: Ah , yes , an epigram to damp my ardor .
‘ Tis not the pin-prick this time , ‘ tis the lash
That drives me headlong toward the wildest dreams .
I 've not the head , you say ? How do you know ?

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Takes the candelabrum in his hand and leads the DUKE to the cheval glass .How do I know ? Just glance into this mirror . Look at the sullen sadness of your face , The grim betrayal of your fair complexion , This crushing golden hair — I bid you look !

lg.stage: Struggling to get out of his grasp .
lg.l: No !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: You 're environed with a fatal mist !

lg.l: Though you know it not , ‘ tis Germany ,
‘ Tis Spain , for ages dormant in your blood ,
Make you so haughty , sorrowful , and charming .
Bethink you of your self-distrust !
You — reign ? Come , come ! You would be pale and wan ;
One of those timid , introspective kings
Who are imprisoned lest they abdicate .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Not yours the energetic brow ! Yours is the brow of languor and of yearning .

lg.stage: Shaking , passes his left hand across his brow .
lg.l: My — brow ?
And drearily your Highness passes
Over an Austrian brow a Spanish hand !
Observe the frail and tapering fingers
Seen fair and jewelled in long lines of portraits !
And those eyes through which your ancestors
Look forth !
Ay ! note them well ! The eyes
Wherein how many eyes we 've seen before
Dream of the fagot , weep for perished squadrons !
Dare you , whose conscience is so sensitive ,
Ascend the throne of France with eyes like those ?
Naught of him is in you !
Search ! Search again ! Come closer to the light !
He stole our ancient blood to mix with his ,
That his might grow more ancient . But he stole
Only the racial melancholy , and
The feebleness , and —

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Look ! Look in the mirror ! You turn pale ?

lg.l: And on your lips you recognize the pout
As of a doll , of Marie Antoinette ,
Her whom your France beheaded ; for your Father ,
While stealing glory , stole mishap as well !
Nay ! raise the chandelier !

div.stage: He forces the chandelier into the DUKE 'S right hand , and holds him by that wrist .

lg.l: You cannot gaze into this glass at night ,
But all your race will gibber at your back !
Look — in the gloom — that shade is Mad Johanna ,
And yonder Thing , that moves so deathly slow ,
Is the pale sovereign in his crystal coffin .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: No ! ‘ Tis the radiant pallor of my Father !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Yonder , recoiling , Rudolph and his lions !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The clash of steeds and weapons ! ‘ Tis the Consul !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Lo ! in a noisome crypt one fashions gold .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: He fashions glory on the sands of Egypt .

lg.l: Aha ! Here 's Charles the Fifth , with hair cropped close ,
Dying for having sought self-burial !
The Escurial ! Grisly phantoms
And frowning walls !
Ah , hither ! smiling visions :
Compiègne and Malmaison !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Roll , drums of Arcola , and drown his voice !

lg.stage: Twisting his wrist loose , but still holding the chandelier .
lg.l: I will shatter it !

lg.stage: Hurling the chandelier into the mirror .
lg.l: ‘ Tis shattered !
Not one remains ! Not one !

lg.stage: Pointing at the DUKE with a terrible gesture .
lg.l: Yes !— One !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: No , no ! It is not I ! Not I !— My Father !— Help !

div.stage: CURTAIN .
Illustration : decoration of five torches with a hand for the flame .

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT

stage.stage: The Park at Schönbrunn . Ruins of a Roman Arch in the centre , in front of which is a fountain . Entrances on the right and on the left . Towards the right , in front , is a pile of stones , parts of columns , a head of Neptune , a broken urn , the whole covered with ivy and shrubs . Orange-trees in boxes , bearing fruit and blossom , are dotted about , with lamps hanging in their foliage . At the rise of the curtain a gay throng of LORDS and LADIES in dominos and other disguises are moving about the stage .

lg.stage: To a lady in a domino .
lg.l: Your ear —
Your ear —

sp.speaker: FIRST MASK
sp.p: Would have delighted in these figures —

lg.l: What for ?
All is uncertain , tremulous , and vague —
Our hearts , the music , moonbeams , and the water .
And so , dear Attaché of the French Embassy ,
Here I 've contrived half-darkness and half-silence ,
And yonder in the music and the light
The ball —

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Rather good , I think . This way —

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: You condescend to be my guide ?

lg.l: Dear friend , I 'm prouder of this little ball ,
Of having mingled all these courtly perfumes
With the wild odors of the midnight woods ,
Than ever of the Congress of Verona .
That is the vestiary and the way out
So that in leaving you may find at once
Your Polish mantle or your overcoat .
Lastly , the theatre which I 've contrived
On yonder bowling-green , near Cupid 's fountain ,
Where , in a set-piece made of natural foliage ,
Some princely amateurs will play “ Michel
And ” — I do n't know — some dainty little piece
By a French author : Eugène — what'shYpppHeNhishYpppHeNname ?
Every box will blossom
With snowy tablecloths and golden dishes .
My own idea . They 'll bring
All they can find . Under each leafy ball
Two couples will be seated , starved and laughing .

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: Supper in short at separate orange-trees ? Splendid .

lg.l: Why , yes .— And as for grave affairs —
Tell them to play no more Slavonic dances —
I do not put them off . Not I. I leave
Ere supper-time to meet the Hospodars —
They are awaiting me —
Those wreaths are skimpy .
My hobby 's organizing balls like this ;
And when the revelry is at its highest
Back to the everlasting Eastern Question !
I love to rule a people and a ball :
The Arbiter of Europe —
Ah ,
You 're talking Latin ; you 've been drinking ?
Fanny has kept you very late at table ;
Oh , this liaison ! you 're as good as lost .
GENTZ .
It 's off .
‘ Twas wrong to bring you , Fanny .
If they discovered you ! What an imprudence !
A public dancer !

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: They 'll find you out . For heaven 's sake be clumsy .

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: Yes ; for the Duke !— and at this ball !

lg.l: Here ! you alarm me !
Be an angel , Fanny ,
And tell me why you wished to come .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: I fear the Duke no more . I 've killed his pride . And he 's in mourning for it . He 'll not come .

lg.l: Poles and Greeks :
Princess Grazalcowitch .
Grazalcowitch !
That 's terrible !
Pray let me have a sandwich .
You laugh ?— Hush !— Here they come . They 've fled the light
And seek a nook to whisper in .

div.stage: Enter several DOMINOS .

lg.l: My dear ,
How sweet it is to run a risk for his sake .
It 's like a pretty little halo , dear ,
Through which a regal crown is dimly seen .
He has a doubly-fascinating charm :—
A fair Napoleon ! Hamlet dressed in white !
First , I suggest we order
A golden bee from Stieger in Vienna .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER DOMINO
sp.p: Vienna ! Why ? That would be idiotic ! We 'll have it made by Odiot in Paris .

lg.l: I move we always wear with every dress
A very striking bunch of violets .
And let us risk returning
To Empire fashions .

sp.speaker: THIRD DOMINO
sp.p: Dear , do n't forget the horrible short waists .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: And all the puffs !— and ruches !— Dearest !

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Go on with your delicious plotting . Conspire ! conspire ! Ha-ha !

div.stage: He goes out , laughing heartily .

lg.l: And now
That thanks to idle chatter we 've removed
Whatever doubts Sedlinzky had aroused ,
We 'll prove that after female Machiavellis
The Metternichest Metternich 's a baby .

sp.speaker: FIRST DOMINO
sp.p: Each remembers what she has to do ?

lg.l: He 's so funny !

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: And who 's the bear , dancing to Schubert 's waltz ?

sp.speaker: A MASK
sp.p: What 's sad Elvira 's dress ? A star ?

lg.l: Not gone to Parma , sister ?

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: No . To-morrow . The Duchess put it off to see this ball .Pointing to a Domino who passes at the back accompanied by a Mask .She 's yonder with Bombelles : the greenish cape .

lg.l: I 'm glad you 're going , for Noblesse oblige ;
I could n't stand much more of those asides
Between the little Bonaparte and you .
‘ Tis our glory that our ancestors
Have not been over-prudish with our kings ;
It is no fall to pick up handkerchiefs
When on the handkerchief a lily 's broidered .
But honor never will accept a rag
Which bears the Bonapartist weed and hornet ,
Woe to the Ogre 's brat —!
How do you know I am a diplomat ?

sp.speaker: THE CHINESE WOMAN
sp.p: Why , by the skilful way you hide your claws .

lg.l: Is there no way of knowing who you are ?
Now , are you English ?
My Lord , is not the ball beyond compare ?
Your ear —!
My secret ! Hush !
Your ear !

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: This corner 's charming , given up to shadows —

lg.l: What are you carrying on your arm ?
Charming , those scattered blocks , the broken god ,
The ivied urn , and , in its frame of stone ,
Yonder the water . It is like —
What had Prince Metternich to say last night ?
You take your mask off ?
And , alas , that 's all
A stone .
To cast into the pond —
All 's vanished . Only circles on the water .
You are depressed , and yet to-night the plot
Must come to a head if I may trust the symptoms .
These lines were slipped into my hand this morning :
lg.stage: He takes a note out of his pocket .
lg.l: “ Ask him to be there early , and to wear
His uniform beneath a violet cloak . ”
The note
Is from a woman anxious not to miss me .
I 've taken her advice , for I am here
Only for love 's adventure .
Oh , ‘ twere too criminal ,
Dear country , made of sunshine and of laughter ,
To raise upon the high seat of thy glory
A child of night , misfortune , and the Escurial !
What if , when I were seated there , the past ,
Plunging its yellow hands into my soul ,
With hideous claws unearthed some ancestor :
Some Rudolph or some Philip ? Ah ! I dread
Lest at the humming of Imperial bees
The monster sleeping in me should awake .
Prince , this is madness !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: With a shudder and a look which makes PROKESCH start back with horror .Madness ! Do you think so ?

lg.l: Buried in their fastnesses ,
Cowering in Bohemia or Castile ,
Each had his madness . What is mine to be ?
Come ! We 'll decide ! You see I am resigned .
‘ Tis time to choose — and I have choice enough :
My thoughtful forebears left a catalogue !
Shall I be melomaniac or astrologer ?
Catch birds , bend o'er alembics , mumble prayers ?

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: Too well I see what Metternich has done !

lg.l: Grandfather , shall I carry on your great
Herbarium , where the hellebore is missing ?
Or shall I , living , play at being dead ?
Which ancestor will godfather my madness ?
The living-dead , the alchemist , or bigot ?
You see , they took their madness rather sadly ,
But mingled perfumes make a novel scent ;
My brain , mixed of these gloomy brains , may start
Some pretty little madness of its own .
Come ! What shall my peculiar madness be ?
By heavens ! My instincts , conquered till to-day ,
Make it quite simple : I 'll be mad with love !
I 'll love and love , and crush , with bitter hate ,
This Austrian lip under a passionate kiss !
As Don Juan I am all my race !
Snarer of hearts , astrologer of eyes ;
I 'll have herbaria full of blighted names ,
And the philosopher 's stone I seek is love !
Why , if you think of it , dear friend ,
Napoleon 's son , Don Juan , is strict logic .
The soul 's the same : ever dissatisfied ;
The same unceasing lust of victory .
Oh splendid blood another has corrupted ,
Who , striving to be Cæsar , was not able ;
Thy energy is not all dead within me .
A misbegotten Cæsar is Don Juan !
Yes , ‘ tis another way of conquering ;
Thus I shall know that fever of the heart
Which Byron tells us kills whom it devours ;
And ‘ tis a way of being still my father .
Napoleon or Don Juan !— They 're decision ,
The magic will , and the seductive grace .
When to retake a great unfaithful land ,
Calm and alone , sure of himself and her ,
The adventurer landed in the Gulf of Juan ,
He felt Don Juan 's thrill ; and when Don Juan
Pricked a new conquest in his list of loves ,
Did he not feel the pride of Bonaparte ?
And , after all , who knows whether ‘ tis greater
To conquer worlds , or be a moment loved ?
So be it ? ‘ Tis well the legend closes thus ,
And that this conqueror is the other 's son .
I 'm the fair shadow of the dusky hero ,
And , as he conquered nations , one by one ,
So will I conquer women , one by one .
Moonbeams shall be my sun of Austerlitz !

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: Ah , silence ! for your irony 's too bitter .

lg.l: Oh , yes ; I know . I hear the spectres crying —
Blue-coated spectres torn along the whirlwind —
“ Well ? What about the Imperial tale of triumph ?
Our toil ? our wounds ? our glory ?— What about
The snow , the blood , the history , the dead
We left on all the fields of victory ?
What will you do with these ? ” — I 'll charm the ladies !
It 's fine , among the people in the Prater ,
To ride a horse that cost three thousand florins ,
Which one can christen Jena . Austerlitz
Is a sure bait to catch a fair coquette .

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: You 'll never have the heart to use it thus .

lg.l: Why , yes ; why , yes , my friend . And in my scarf —
For ‘ tis a thing looks well upon a lover —
I 'll wear a dainty eaglet for a pin .
There 's music !— Now , O Cæsar 's son , you 're but
Mozart 's Don Juan ! Nay , not even Mozart 's !
Strauss 's ! I 'll waltz ; for now I must become
Charming and useless : Austrian fancy-goods !
My aunt ?— Why —!

div.stage: PROKESCH goes out .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: How deep the linden 's perfume is to-night .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Notice my salver . I 'm so proud of it .

lg.l: The “ Chocolate-girl , ” the famous
Picture in Dresden .
Cha'ming . But your chocolate
Must be a nuisance .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Well , Franz ? A little bit in love with life ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Glad to be nephew of a pretty aunt .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: And I am glad to have so big a nephew .

lg.l: Ah , now I see ! As all the court is masked ,
Even friendship wears the domino of love .
Oh friendship — auntie with a cousin 's eyes —
Friendship and love are always much too near
‘ Twixt aunts and nephews , god-sons and god-mothers —
Oh ! do but smell the fragrance of the lindens !—
‘ Twixt pretty chocolate-girls and officers ,
And frontier incidents are bound to happen .
I dearly love
This sentiment one cannot understand ,
Where all 's confused and mingled —

div.stage: She moves away .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Oh , if you put on airs of an Archduchess —!

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Farewell ; you 've pained me deeply , Franz .

div.stage: She goes .

lg.l: Ah , bah !
Into our friendship I let fall a drop ,
And friendship turns to troubled love . I 'll wait .
Why ! What is this ? How comes it you are here ?
So you 're not hastening toward the skies of Parma ?
And all this grass ? What are you ?
Ah , yes , I know . An exile on his rock ,
My father had a brooklet for his friend
To drown the gaoler 's voice , and that is why
At Schönbrunn , which is my Saint Helena ,
My soul must not be left deprived of comfort .
Having the gaoler I 've the brooklet too .

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: But you will never stoop to look at me .

lg.l: Because I dreamed of flying from my rock ;
But that 's all over .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: All hope is gone . I wake from dreams .

lg.l: Little Brooklet
Must give her murmuring freshness .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: What if I trouble its waters ?

lg.l: Come to the little house among the trees —
My hunting lodge — to-night !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Say neither yes nor no .— I 'll wait —

lg.l: Think how unhappy I shall henceforth be !
I 've lost all hope of playing a great part ;
I can but weep ; I need a heart to weep on .
Away !

lg.stage: Seeing a stout lady dressed as a shepherdess .
lg.l: That shepherdess has eaten her flock !
The Viscount 's here as Doge in grand dalmatic .

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: Then is the Baroness the Adriatic .

lg.stage: Who has scribbled a note ; to a LACKEY .
lg.l: This for my lackeys . I shall not come in .
I 'm sleeping at the hunting-lodge . Make haste !
Let me have word they 've read and understood .

sp.speaker: Violet cloak
sp.p: Prokesch ! I said your note was from a woman !

lg.stage: Pointing to the ATTACHÉ , who has followed her .
lg.l: Let me get rid of this importunate mask .
And I 'll come back .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I 'll wait . ‘ Tis fate . I yield . I 'll love , with stormy April in my heart . I 'll love — like these — like all !

lg.stage: Who has come in with MARIA LOUISA . She sits on the stone bench .
lg.l: Was he in love ?

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: What ! must you still be harping on him ?

lg.l: I do n't know .
He was intimidated in my presence .
Even on his throne , beneath his golden laurels ,
He felt his inequality of birth ;
And then , to keep a countenance , he 'd call me
His “ Good Louisa . ” Yes ! such shocking taste !
For I love sentiment . I am a woman .
A little thing I said
When Saint Aulaire came to my room at Blois
With news of his disasters , made them furious .
I was in bed . My naked foot peeped out ,
And , lying on the polished wood , as if
Thomire had carved it , seemed at once to turn
The Medicean bed into an Empire bed .
And seeing the Envoy furtively look down ,
I smiled and said , “ You 're looking at my foot . ”
And so he was . In spite of all misfortunes ,
Indeed the man was looking at my foot .
Was this coquettish ? Well , what of it ? Heavens !
Where was the crime if I remained a woman ?
For , after all , amid the crash of France ,
The beauty of my foot had some importance !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Would I could fly ! but I am glued to the spot !

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: What 's the grey pebble in your bracelet ?

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: That ? Ah , I can never see it without tears . That is a fragment —

lg.l: What nonsense ! ‘ Tis a fragment of the tomb
Where Juliet sleeps beside her Romeo —
I had this souvenir —
For pity 's sake
Do n't mention Neipperg !
If he irritates you ,
Why speak about the first ?
That 's different ,
But did you love him ?

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: So great a man ! You must —

lg.l: Oh , as for that ,
No man is ever loved because he 's great .
Let 's talk of him no more : let 's talk of us .
Will you like Parma ?
So much so that he drove away Leroy ,
Because the poor man-milliner cried out
With admiration when he saw my shoulders ,
While trying on a peplum .
Would not have liked to hear me say
How fair they are ? Would not have liked —

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: To hear me whisper to your Majesty —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Father , forgive me for the things I hear !

lg.l: That you are like our own Arlesian maids
But , ah ! how much more beautiful !—

sp.speaker: BOMBELLES
sp.p: Would not have liked to see me bend and press — -

lg.l: Not that ! I will not have it ! I forbid you !—
Thank God , I 'm saved !
For this cry , this movement
Were not my own . Within me still remains
A reverence for my mother and her freedom !
‘ Twas he — ‘ Twas he by whom my soul 's possessed ,
Who sprang upon you with this tragic force !
Thank God ! I 'm saved ! The Corsican leapt out !
Nothing , sir !
My humble duty , Madam !
Return to Sala , spend your days in peace .
The castle has two wings , as I am told :
One is a theatre and one a chapel .
Thus dwelling in the middle , you shall feel
Evenly balanced ‘ twixt the world and God .
My humble duty !
Why , truly , Madam ,
It 's your prerogative to be mere woman .
Go , be a woman in the Sala palace ;
But tell yourself , Ah ! tell yourself — and this
Shall be your sad atonement for his glory ,
Widow who cast aside her widow 's weeds !—
Tell yourself this : Men only gaze upon you
For the immortal fame he robed you in ,
And only whisper praises of your beauty
Because of old he conquered all the world !

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: I 'll hear no more ! Bombelles , let us begone !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Return to Sala . I am saved . Thank God !

lg.l: O hands , cold hands within the tomb ,
Sad hands because the Imperial ring slipped from you ,
Hands that have held her brow who years ago
Shed bitter tears that I was not her son ,
Hands laid in blessing on my orphaned soul ,
Weeping I kiss you , hands of Josephine !

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: The Creole ! Do you think at Malmaison —?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Silence ! If it be true , all the more reason ! All the more reason why I should be faithful !

div.stage: MARIA LOUISA and BOMBELLES go out . ] [ Enter METTERNICH and SEDLINZKY .

lg.l: Yes , yes ; I humbled that rebellious child !
You here ? And in this uniform ? What means ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Were we not asked to come here in — disguise ?

lg.l: The pride your Excellency broke last night
Even in its fragments keeps its insolence .
What are you dreaming of , far from the ball ,
My little Colonel ?

lg.stage: On the point of breaking out .
lg.l: Oh , I —
But I must go to my despatches .
‘ Tis all to do again !

div.stage: He and SEDLINZKY go out . ] [ Enter FANNY ELSSLER .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: No ! that woman ! I will not —!

lg.l: Fly ?
Fanny !

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: I 'm in it . Let me tell you —

lg.l: Look innocent .
Sit down . Pretend you 're very much in love .
You on the rock . I on the Neptune 's head .
May I sit down , good Neptune ?

sp.speaker: THE STONE HEAD
sp.p: If you like . Only I warn you , it 's all over ants .

lg.l: Ah ! beneath the ivy !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: The entrance to my cavern through an ant-heap .

div.stage: They pass out .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Oh , yes ; I smoke my pipe —

lg.l: You copied from the beggar
Who first invented bearskins , so they say ,
And had a funny Mameluke called Friday .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: It 's on the right . Here , where I blow a cloud out of my pipe .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Uncomfortable . But then — I said you 'd find me at the ball .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: If they should catch us talking to a smoke !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: An attack of ants . Since yesterday we 've had the bloodiest battles .

lg.l: They outnumber me , but I 've tobacco ,
I blow a blast —

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: May I lift up my rock a bit ?

lg.l: Nuns !
Now I look as if I took the air
On the tomb 's balcony .
And in the moon
Beside the urn , uplifting thus the stone ,
You 're rising to the ghostly night-review .

lg.stage: To some SERVANTS who enter bearing dishes .
lg.l: What 's that you carry ?

div.stage: The SERVANTS stop . The DUKE takes a little of everything .
Stopping them .

p.stage: She takes what is left . The SERVANTS pass out .

lg.l: My strength returns .
Explain . We 've little time .
Well , then — the Countess — she is here — the Countess —
That 's how my nerve goes when I have to dance —
She wears beneath a russet cloak your uniform ,
With which the Eaglet 's turned into a sea-mew .
She was already like you in the face ,
But since she 's dyed her sable tresses fair
Your glass could not distinguish you from her .
So , while they play their “ Michel and Christine , ”
You 'll change your mantle quickly with your cousin —
And openly
Leaves the assembly —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Till I am miles away . Only —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Quite a big one . Suppose the false Duke 's spoken to ?

lg.l: Impossible .
It 's all stage-managed like a ballet . Ladies
Will flutter round him , keep intruders off ,
And as a ball from racket flies to racket
Hell pass from hand to hand until he 's safe .
Who is the wolf ? Wow ! Wow ! Who is the bear ? There ! There !

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Listeners . I fan myself . Glance at your humble servant 's pretty fan .

lg.l: I 've drawn a sketch-map of the park .
Observe the road ; it 's red ; it makes a bend ;
Do you see ? The little squares of white are statues ;
The little dots of apple-green are trees ;
Thus you elude the evil-minded spies ;
Turn to the left ; pass by the pheasantry —
Where the hill goes up .
Then you go down again ; pass by the Triton
And come out Emperor at this little gate .
All clearly understood ?— I shut my fan .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: That 's right . Get out your robes and crown ! Do n't go so fast !

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: With spanking horses ; have no fear .

lg.l: Out of your way , but so the Countess
Would have it :— Wagram .
Dear little Tanagra ,
I 'll recompense your zeal —

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: He 'll be waiting for you there .

lg.l: The only man whose eye we had to fear —
Prince Metternich — has left . All will go well .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Metternich gone ! You never said a word !

lg.l: And you let me catch my death , beneath
This beastly urn —!

sp.speaker: MASKS
sp.p: Sandor ! Zichy ! It 's Thalberg !— Never !— Thalberg is a Turk ! It 's Cocica !— Not he !— He 's fled !— Oh ! catch him !

lg.stage: Emerging , dressed as in the previous act .
lg.l: Then —

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: I 'll tell you what they 'll say —

lg.l: And this one ! Oh ! a veteran of the Empire !
Well , there you are , you see ! That 's what they 'll say .
Come and admire the veteran !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: But how shall I get out without a cloak ?

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Here 's Gentz 's ticket : such a handsome mantle .

div.stage: The USHER enters , followed by SERVANTS who push on orange-trees , the boxes laid as tables .

lg.l: They understand , my Lord . The hunting-lodge .
I had forgotten . I gave orders —
I was to spend the night there . Warn the Countess .
Run ! Run and say ‘ tis thither she must go !
Francesco Duc de Reichstadt ]
Well , Sergeant ? So you served —
The gr-reat !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: They did n't laugh when we were quartered on ‘ em !

sp.speaker: EXCLAMATIONS
sp.p: A picture by Raffet !— Charlet !— Vernet !

lg.l: How worn his coat is !— And how singed !— And dusty !—
Who 's your costumier ?— Tell us !
They are ladies :—
The ancient firm of War and Victory Sisters .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: It 's not the firm you patronize .

lg.l: I 'll swear it 's Zichy .
Offering his hand . ]
Count , your hand .

p.stage: Blowing a puff of smoke in his face .

lg.l: FIRST MASK .
He 's masked his language as he 's masked his face .
When we marched to Krasnoï ,
Cold and hungry , too , were we !
He 's really excellent . In Russia , old ‘ un ,
‘ Twas pretty cold ?
Yes ; till we gave ‘ em hell .
By Jingo , but it keeps you warm
Merely to see his uniform !

sp.speaker: A MASK
sp.p: His uniform wants patching now , though ; what ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: So did your breeches when he 'd kicked you ; what ?

lg.l: I 'm back again . The Countess understands .
Will you accept a veteran 's arm ?
I 'm leaving , sir . Apart from that , I 'm French ,
And see no humor in a parody
Of heroes whom by chance you conquered .
You —
Ah ! I adore you !

div.stage: She runs away . Just as she is disappearing the DUKE makes a movement toward her .

lg.l: No — nothing .
She must keep it . She must show
Whether she would have been sublimely weak ,
And given herself unthinking — without hope —
Only because she saw me sad to-night .
Watch where they 've got to in the comedy .
lg.stage: FLAMBEAU goes to the entrance of the theatre .
lg.l: The time has come .
All eyes are running over
With grief for Stanislas , the mournful Pole .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: My very image ! I 'm coming toward myself as in a glass .

div.stage: The COUNTESS CAMERATA enters , dressed exactly like the DUKE , with the exception of her cloak , which is brown .

lg.l: I see the risks
You 'll run for my sake .

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: No ! For the name , the glory , and our blood !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: You bravely clash your arms , fair Amazon !

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: The deed were nothing , were it done for love .

lg.l: Speaking of love , if , when you 've taken my place
In yonder hunting-lodge , by any chance
A woman came —

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: Ah ! I felt sure of it !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Tell her about my flight — and swear to me —

lg.stage: At the entrance to the theatre , describing the play .
lg.l: The soldier holds his tongue !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Swear you will tell me later if she comes .

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: Thinking of hearts , when Empire is at hand !

lg.l: It is because I mount a throne to-morrow
I lay such value on a heart to-night .
O God ! to feel respect in every kiss ,
Snares in avowals , in embraces dread ,
And in fair eyes , more dazzled than in love ,
See laurel-wreaths about me as on coins !
I was to pluck my last real love to-night !
He 's telling them about his pocket-book .
I would she kept this white and spotless tryst ,
She who has not yet studied to dissemble ;
‘ Twere well she came , for nevermore , perchance ,
Whatever later trysts I yet may keep ,
Shall I be waiting with such eager love ,
As at the tryst to-night I may not keep .

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: I find your Highness very deeply stirred .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Less than I shall be if you say “ She came . ”

lg.l: We must make haste , for with his eyes turned up ,
He 's singing something to his colonel .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Wait for the signal . Have no fear ; I 'm watching . Attention ! By the magic of my wand !

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: Think well ! Perhaps you turn him into Cæsar !

lg.l: That 's why my wand is fashioned of a ramrod .
lg.stage: Noise of people leaving the theatre .
lg.l: They 're coming ! Now !

div.stage: The DUKE and the COUNTESS exchange cloaks .

lg.l: They 've dressed the orange-trees !

lg.stage: To the DUKE , pointing to the COUNTESS .
lg.l: There 's our swarm of women buzzing round him .
Prince !— Duke —! My Lord —! Your Highness —!
No one else
Has any chance to-night !
Sandor ! Zichy ! Mina !

sp.speaker: ANOTHER MASK
sp.p: We 'll gather oranges for our dessert .

lg.l: Duke —

sp.speaker: MASKS
sp.p: Danube sterlets ! Caviar from the Volga !

div.stage: All are seated .

lg.l: Ladies and gentlemen —
Now comes
The trying moment .
I have filled this bumper
In honor —
Of our friend ,
Who , having organized the feast , has left us
Amid the music , flowers , delicious ices ,
To toil till dawn dictating his despatches .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: How well she imitates your careless stride !

lg.l: To the Prince-chancellor , Counsellor , Chamberlain ,
Ladies and gentlemen , drain brimming glasses !
Metternich , Austrian Prince , Grandee of Spain ,
Duke of Portella , Lord of Daruvar —

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: She 's coming forward ! Look how calm she is !

lg.l: He helps us with his chatter ,
And does n't know it .
Knight o ’ the Swedish Seraphs ,
The Danish Elephant , the Golden Fleece —

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: If Nepomuk has one or two more titles —

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: Curator of the Fine Arts , Czechish Magnate —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: She 's overdoing it : I move more quickly .

lg.l: Grand Cross
Of Charles the Third , the Falcon , Bear , and Lion —
Phew —!

lg.stage: To the LADY seated next to GENTZ .
lg.l: He 's fainting ! Fan him quickly , someone !

sp.speaker: GENTZ
sp.p: Fellow of all the Academies on earth —!

lg.l: And while they clash their glasses , Prince ,
She 's starting — she has started —
Franz ! Not going ?
Wait !
The Archduchess
Knew nothing of the plot —
You grieved me , Franz ;
Just now you —
Ah !
But —
lg.stage: Offering her hand to the COUNTESS .
lg.l: Well , good-night .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Why do n't you kiss my hand ?

div.stage: The COUNTESS goes out .

lg.l: Your hand — as to the Duke ?
I wanted to complete my little toast ,
But while the Duke was here I could n't name
The proudest title Metternich can boast of ;
But now we 're rid of him , I have the honor :—
Ladies and gentlemen , here 's the destroyer
Of Bonaparte !
What are you doing ?

lg.stage: Who is pouring his wine into his gun-barrel .
lg.l: Lest it might go off !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Have a care ! An Empire is at stake !

lg.l: A middling soldier ,
But then he rode a camel while in Egypt ;
What more do you want ?
Remember , you 're not here at all !

lg.stage: Arranging his hair , and striking the conventional attitude .
lg.l: Curl — eye — hand — There !
He mocks him , yet
Even the mockery 's great , for it evokes him .

sp.speaker: TIBURTIUS
sp.p: You know he used to tumble off his horse ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: That 's what the Ultras always said about him .

lg.l: Oh , that 's the rule .
What could these worms and insects talk about
If they had not the eagle to abuse ?

sp.speaker: TIBURTIUS
sp.p: His name was not Napoleon at all .

sp.speaker: TIBURTIUS
sp.p: That was manufactured . It 's so simple ! You want to make a sounding name —

lg.l: Which shall creep into history by and by :
Take three bright , simple vowels : Na — po — le —
And add a nasal sound : On —

sp.speaker: TIBURTIUS
sp.p: Yes : Na — po — le , the lightning ; On , the thunder .

lg.l: Be damned !
Bravo the Veteran !
Nicholas !— Have a quail .
But Nicholas was good at winning battles .

sp.speaker: A MASK
sp.p: And what a funny court he scraped together !

lg.l: If you talked titles , pedigrees , precedence ,
There was n't a soul who had a word to say .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Was n't Cambronne at Court to say the word ?

sp.speaker: A MASK
sp.p: And always stood about on distant hills .

lg.l: Once a ball was good enough
To wound him in the foot at Ratisbon :
Enough to make a subject for a picture .
Be calm —!

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: He 'd best be careful what he says .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: You must put up with it !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Aha ! Thank God , there was a man among them !

lg.l: He 's the Attaché
Of the French Embassy .
You challenge me !
You represent the King , sir !
The King is not in question , but my country .
You are insulting France , when you insult
The man she loved through many glorious years .

lg.stage: Who has disappeared for a moment , and has come back cloaked .
lg.l: Come ! I 've got Gentz 's cloak . It 's lined with fur .

div.stage: TIBURTIUS and the ATTACHÉ have exchanged cards . TIBURTIUS steps forward and nervously lights a cigar .

sp.speaker: A light
sp.p: THE LACKEY . You hate the Corsican ?

sp.speaker: THE LACKEY
sp.p: Your sister loves his son . Would you surprise them ?

sp.speaker: TIBURTIUS
sp.p: Wait for me here . Austria shall be relieved .

lg.stage: Placing his hand on the ATTACHÉ 'S shoulder .
lg.l: I thank you , sir .
What for , sir ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I 've nothing but my secret . Now it 's yours . We meet to-night at Wagram . Be there .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Are you not one of us ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: But you 're to fight a duel for my Father . And so we 're somewhat brothers . Fare-you-well .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I am sure to win you . Did not my Sire win Philippe de Ségur ?

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: To-morrow I return to France . I warn you —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: You are a future Marshal of the Empire .

lg.l: I warn you , if my regiment meets yours
I shall not hesitate to fire .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Of course not . Shake hands before we cut each other 's throats .

lg.l: If you have any messages for Paris ,
I get there on the fourth ; I should be happy —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I hope to be there , sir , ahead of you .

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: Yet , if I reach the — kingdom — ere you come ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Salute for me the Column of Vendôme !

div.stage: CURTAIN .
Illustration
Illustration

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT

stage.stage: The battle-field of Wagram . Night . A small hill running off toward the left . A sign-post stands on the hill .
The DUKE is standing on the summit of the hill gazing across the battle-field . PROKESCH and FLAMBEAU are talking together in undertones near the front .

lg.l: “ My son shall reign — a mighty sovereign — ”

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Capital bit of country for the harvest .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: “ His task to foster whatsoe'er is good . ”

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: What solemn prayer is he reciting ?

lg.l: “ Complete my work , and not avenge my death —
All patriots — ”
The horses ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: “ He would but ape me , if he made great wars — ”

sp.speaker: PROKESCH
sp.p: He is rehearsing all his Father 's counsels .

lg.l: “ He shall scorn all parties — ”
Well ? The horses .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Like an impatient lover I 've come too early to my tryst with France .He takes a few strides and finds himself in front of a sign-post .Their sign-post ! Is it true that I shall move Unhindered by their hideous black and yellow ? How good to read upon the gleaming white “ Road to Saint Cloud ” instead of “ Grosshofen . ” Grosshofen ? Now I think of it , I ordered My regiment to Grosshofen at dawn .

lg.l: Yes ; I gave the order yesterday ,
Before I knew .

div.stage: An old man comes out of the cottage .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: He 's ours . His hut our meeting-place . Old soldier . Shows the battle-field to strangers .

lg.l: Why
Does he serve us ?
I was dying yonder ;
The great Napoleon passed —
He always rode
Over a battle-field .
The Emperor stopped
And had me cared for by his leach —
So , if his son is weary of Vienna ,
I 'll help him go .— My arm — before his eyes !
It is n't everybody has the honor
Of having limbs off in Napoleon 's presence .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Some grimy officer rode up . And roared , “ We 've conquered ! ”

lg.l: What ?— So he did .
Suppose he heard !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Should n't wonder . For on this spot eleven drummer-boys —

lg.l: I see them now !
Eleven bullet-heads , as like as peas ,
Between the flapping of their foolish ears ,
Who marched , they knew not whence , nor why , nor whither ,
But gayly marched and rolled their rataplan !
We used to chaff them , for their funny ways
Made them the darlings of the sutler 's wife .
But when they beat the charge like little rabbits —
Eleven drums with two-and-twenty sticks —
They set our bayonets thrilling with their thunder ;
The quivering zigzags seemed to cry aloud ,
“ Our lightning 's not in vain ! ” — Well , on this spot ,
A brazen devil hiccoughed fire and steel
And took them in the flank ; yes ! all the eleven !
But , by the Lord ! you should have seen the woman !
She gathered up her apron like a gleaner ,
And madly gleaned the little ebony drumsticks .
Only to speak of it gives me a cold —!
Here 's how to make a mere geranium
A ribbon of the Legion : keep one petal .
What ? You look well upon my velvet lining ?
Is this what you bestowed upon me , Sire ?
Those shadows —?
Marmont ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Why do the others stand so far away ?

lg.l: Because they fear they may disturb your Highness ,
And , Sire , you are already Emperor !
The word strikes strangely on my wondering ear —
The Emperor ! What Emperor is here ?
This youth of twenty on the throne ?
As through a casement now myself I see
Pass down the shouting street ; ‘ tis good to be
Young , and the first Napoleon 's son !
All Notre Dame invades my dreaming soul ,
I see the incense , hear the organ roll ,
A nation offers up a prayer !
God ! what great causes may be served by kings !
How they can love ! Achieve what righteous things !
Prokesch , the Future shows too fair !
O France , who with thy blood didst write our name ,
With happy days I will repay the fame ;
I come , triumphant in my pride .
Sun on my flags ; the air with shouts is rent .
The Champs Elysées , with their chestnut scent ,
Waft me fair welcome as I ride .
The women stand on chairs to see your face ,
Each the fair symbol of Parisian grace ,
The guns in wreaths of flowers are dressed ;
Fierce Paris madly hails your sovereignship .
It were like kissing France upon the lip
If Paris took me to her breast .
And you will hear the sufferer 's complaint ;
Do you not feel your hand already faint
Signing so many an amnesty ?
The lies they 've told me make the truth more dear ,
Oh , Freedom , Freedom , thou hast nought to fear
From one so late from bonds set free !
What can I do to foster noble aims ?
Treviso , Montebello , these are names
Their sons inherit without fear ,
But other names are glorious , and since
My Father would have made Corneille a Prince
I 'll make our Victor Hugo Peer !
I 'll do — I 'll do — I 'll be the poor man 's shield !
The heroic savour , rising from this field ,
Gives me a foretaste of my home ;
Wagram ! ‘ Twas well I hither came to drain
The stirrup-cup upon thy glorious plain !
Oh , my beloved France !— I come —!
Ah —!

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Yes , to the marrow , but a gallop cures me . Stars twinkle in the skies like golden rowels . Here are the steeds , and we 're to ride to France ! Embrace me , friend !

lg.l: Ah , hush !— The saddle-girth !—
Oh , it 's delicious to escape on horseback
Through such a night , in dancing-pumps !

lg.stage: To MARMONT , pointing to the Conspirators .
lg.l: Those youths —
Why have they come ?
Why , that the world may know
They also were conspirators !
The Viscount of Otranto —
No matter now .
The stirrup long ?
Goubeaux , the Countess Camerata 's agent .
Your humble servant Goubeaux —
The Countess 's chief agent .
Pionnet —
I 'm Pionnet . I represent King Joseph ;
On his behalf I brought the subsidies .

lg.stage: To FLAMBEAU , busy with the horse .
lg.l: Only the snaffle —
I arranged the guides
And relays , and at yonder village , Sire ,
Disguises — Morchain .

sp.speaker: FIFTH CONSPIRATOR
sp.p: I got the passports . Thankless task ! See how the seals are forged ! Guibert .

lg.l: Goubeaux —
Morchain — Otranto — Pionnet —

sp.speaker: ONE OF THE CONSPIRATORS
sp.p: Your Father had a memory for names .

lg.l: Borowski , Sire ! It was my glorious task
To hire the uniform the Countess wears !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Enough ! Enough ! I shall remember all , And best of all the one who has not spoken ! Your name ?The man spoken to turns , and the DUKE recognises the ATTACHÉ .What ! You here !

lg.l: Not as partisan .
Only as friend . Indeed no slight occasion
Was needed —
Mount !
The dawn is in the east ,
I seize the reins , and — Alea jacta est !
My Lord , if I have sought this rendezvous ,
‘ Twas to defend you —

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: I feared you were in danger —

lg.l: The rogue Tiburtius , whom I hope to pink ,
Sneaked from the ball and never sent his seconds ,
So I ran after him , and saw him meet
Another rogue , and heard the two conspire
To kill you at some rendezvous .

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: The rendezvous was here , as you had told me . I came . All 's well . I go .

lg.l: The rendezvous
Was in the hunting-lodge . They 'll kill the Countess !
We must go back !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Alas , you little know her . She 'd die ten times to let me win ten minutes . Come back !

lg.l: But I cannot — Ah , come back !—
I cannot let them kill her in my absence !
If we re-conspire
They will not let you fly .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: To leave her were to cast my soul away !

sp.speaker: MARMONT
sp.p: Risk — for a woman — all the chance of triumph —!

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: He 's a French Prince ! That 's certain , anyhow !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: I 'll run you through the body if you touch him !

lg.l: Back ! or with whip uplifted I will charge
After the fashion of Murat , my uncle !

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: We shall have to force him .

lg.l: And you , who say you came in my defence ,
It is by robbing me of faith and scruple ,
They would assassinate me truly ! Now , defend me !

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: Go , Sire , I will defend the woman .

sp.speaker: THE ATTACHÉ
sp.p: Begone , my Lord . Whate'er I do is for the Countess .

lg.l: Yes ,
But I —
I cannot —
Unhappy boy ! Not gone !
You !— but they told me —
How could I go ?

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: A woman 's life ! What loss would that have been ?

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: Think of the time you 've lost !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And all our fears on your behalf —

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: What fears ? Was not your Flambeau , there , my fencing-master ?

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: Oh , nothing . Of course he drew his sword , and I drew mine .

lg.l: “ I did not know , ” he muttered ,
“ The Corsican 's son had so much skill , I think
He knew it not himself ” — But then my voice —
Scratched across the fingers .
My voice betrayed me . Back he sprang ! “ A woman ! ”
“ Defend yourself ! ” said I , “ I should be laughed at ,
For you are not the Chevalier d'Eon ! ”
“ Defend yourself , I 'm a Napoleon ! ”
Feeling my blade slip snake-like over his ,
He lunges , and I make —

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: That must have been a rough surprise !

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: ‘ Twas a surprise from which he 'll not recover .

lg.l: Well — No , then ! When the door
Was broken open by a furious fist ,
I was alone . She had not come .
But servants came ; and if I were arrested
All would be known too soon . I lost my head .
I stumbled out . I heard I know not whom
Sending to fetch the Prefect of Police ;
And so I fled upon your saddle-horse .
I 've killed it — I 'm exhausted —
After what I had done I hoped at least
To hear from witnesses that you were gone !

sp.speaker: A CONSPIRATOR
sp.p: You were pursued — And in a moment —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Take care of her . Conceal her in the hut .

lg.l: Not yet gone ?
For God 's sake , go ! Ah ! could your Father see you
Waiting , enfeebled , tender , hesitating ,
With what contempt he 'd shrug his epaulettes !

lg.stage: Entering with police officers ; he advances to the COUNTESS , whom he mistakes for the DUKE .
lg.l: Too late , my Lord .
Ah , Temporizer ! Dreamer ! Cold Idealist !

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: Who has turned to the person addressed by the COUNTESS and recognized the DUKE , starts , and , addressing him .Your Highness —He turns to the COUNTESS .Your High —To the DUKE .Your High —

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: You 've been drinking . You see double .

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: Count Prokesch , I must ask you to retire .

div.stage: PROKESCH exit .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: We sha n't be crowned just yet by Uncle Fesch !

lg.l: Lead off this gentleman . You , sir , in this ?
Your Government shall hear of it .
I swear
He was not of the plot !
Forgive me , Sire ,
Since they 're arresting us I take my share .

lg.stage: To the ATTACHÉ , as he is led off .
lg.l: Good-bye , then .
Now , policeman , show your zeal .

lg.stage: To his men , pointing to the COUNTESS .
lg.l: Take the false Prince wherever — she — belongs .
With all the honors due to me !

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: That voice ! Ah , hapless child ! You would have made a leader !

div.stage: She is led off .

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: As for the rest , we 'll shut our eyes : Verb . sap .

div.stage: All disappear .

lg.l: Open your eyes again . Here 's one more left .
‘ Tis he !

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: How can we make sure !The POLICEMAN hands him a paper , which he reads .“ Nose ordinary , eyes ordinary , Mouth ordinary — ” Extraordinary !Watching FLAMBEAU .Two bullets in his — back .

lg.l: I 'm lost . All right ; I 'll have my little joke ,
And deck myself in flowers ere dropping out .

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: You answer to the name of Seraph Flambeau .

lg.l: No , sir ! That name 's not good enough to die with .
I 'll be drum-major in the Dance of Death ;
Not merely Seraph , nor Flambeau , the torch .
I broaden ! I 'm Archangel Chandelier !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Will you deliver him to France ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Like a thief ? You have no right , sir —!

lg.l: ‘ Twas getting past a joke that I should never
Be present when they wanted to behead me .

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: Also his decoration is illegal . Take off that ribbon !

lg.l: Take it . But it grows
As often as I choose on my old hide .

div.stage: Unseen by the others he stabs himself .

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: Take off his cloak !When the cloak is removed , the spot of blood shows like the ribbon of the Legion of Honor on FLAMBEAU 'S shirt .What 's that ?

lg.l: My Lord , this leaves me not
Till death !

sp.speaker: SEDLINZKY
sp.p: What ! He has pinned another on !

lg.l: You cannot make an end ! I 've pinned another ;
And when that 's gone , another , and another !

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: What did they do to Ney ?

lg.l: A little firing-party —
Rrrrrr !
I always laughed at bullets ;
But French ones ? Never ! None of that , Lisette !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: You will not give him up ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Seraph , your wings are clipped ; good-night , my friend !

lg.stage: On his knees ; knocking off the policeman 's hat .
lg.l: The Duke is speaking ! Take that stovepipe off !
No ! I 've pinned on
An everlasting ribbon of the Legion !
I 'll not allow one of your men to touch him :
What ! the clean soldier touched by soiled policemen !
Leave us alone together . Go !— Begone !

lg.stage: To a policeman , pointing to the old man of the hut .
lg.l: Lead off that peasant .

div.stage: The old man is led off .

lg.l: I 'll await
My regiment . ‘ Tis summoned here at dawn .
The standards shall salute him , and the drums ,
And my own soldiers shall uplift his body .
Where are the horses ?
SEDLINZKY .
Then let him be .
Highness , we cede .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I turn you out ! For on the field of Wagram I 'm at home !

div.stage: SEDLINZKY and the policeman go .

lg.l: It 's funny , all the same , that on this field
Where I was wounded for the Father , now
I perish for the son .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: No ! not for me ! It is for him : I am not worth your death .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: For him ! This is the field of Wagram .

lg.l: Do you not recognize
Wagram , the field , the hill , the pointed steeple ?
Do you see the Austrian cannon yonder
All painted yellow , belching fire and smoke ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Do you hear the noise of it ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: I die at Wagram ! Ah ! I die at Wagram !

lg.l: Do you not see the wounded horse rush by ,
Dragging his slaughtered rider by the stirrups ?
We are at Wagram ! ‘ Tis a solemn moment .
Davoust has come to turn Neusiedel 's flank ;
The Emperor has raised his little spy-glass ;
You have been wounded by a bayonet ,
And I have brought you to this little hill .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: But the light cavalry ? Have n't they charged ?

lg.l: Yonder the blue , striped with white shoulder-belts :
Those are the Infantry .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The Emperor should send Oudinot to help ! He lets his left be crushed !

lg.l: They fight ! They fight ! Macdonald hastens up ,
And wounded Massena drives slowly by .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: If the Archduke deploys his right he 's lost .

lg.l: The Prince of Auersburg
Is taken by the Polish Lancers of the Guard .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: The Emperor ? What 's the Emperor doing ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Is the Archduke caught in the little ‘ un 's trap ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The distant dust-cloud yonder is Nansouty .

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: Has the Archduke not yet deployed his right ?

sp.speaker: FLAMBEAU
sp.p: I thirst !— I stifle — Drink ! What — is — the — Emperor doing ?

lg.l: With a smile
He shuts his little spy-glass .
Victory !
Flambeau !
lg.stage: He looks at him , and moves away a little .
lg.l: This dying soldier frightens me .
Yet ‘ tis not strange a dying grenadier
Should fall asleep upon this field of glory .
The field is well acquainted with his likes .
lg.stage: He bends over him and cries .
lg.l: Yes ! Victory ! The soldiers toss their shakos !
I thirst —!
What are those echoes ?
I die — I die !
His voice
Reverberates beneath the lurid sky .
I understand ! His cries of death
Are , for this vale which knows them all by heart ,
As the first measures of a well-known song .
The plain takes up the moaning death has hushed .
I understand ! complaints and sobs !—
‘ Tis Wagram 's field , remembering aloud !
How still he lies !— I must begone !
For ‘ tis as if he 'd fallen in the battle !
lg.stage: And bending over him he murmurs .
lg.l: Thus and no otherwise they must have looked !
The uniform — the blood —!
lg.stage: He is about to go , but suddenly , with horror .
lg.l: Another ! There !
There —! Everywhere —! The same accusing shapes !
They 're dying thus as far as eye can reach !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: I hear them speaking in the gloom !

lg.l: My brow bleeds —! My leg is dead —! My arm hangs loose !—
I 'm crushed beneath this gun !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The battle-field ! I 've willed it : it has risen .

lg.l: Water !— Water
Upon my gash ! Ah ! tell me what I 've broken !
Ah ! do not let me perish in this ditch !
Forests of arms are quivering in the plain ;
I tread upon a field of epaulettes .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: And I slip on leather shoulder-belts !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Horrible ! The wooden soldiers ranged upon my table !

sp.speaker: THE VOICES
sp.p: Horses have trampled on me ! Drink !— The ravens ! I 'm dying !— How I suffer !— God forgive me ! The ravens !— Help !

sp.speaker: THE VOICES
sp.p: Water !— This brook runs blood !— Yet let me drink ! I thirst !— I die !— God 's curse !— I 'm hurt !— Mother !

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: For God 's sake ! put a bullet through my head !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Ah ! Now I understand my wakeful nights —

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: Curse the Light Cavalry ! They 're base assassins !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The racking cough that wakes me in a sweat !

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: I cannot drag my leg ! Oh , wrench it off !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The blood I spit ! I know whose blood it is !

lg.l: And all the arms ! And all the arms I see !
The handless wrists ! The hands with shattered fingers !
The monstrous harvest which a mighty wind
Bends me-ward with a curse ! Oh ! Mercy ! Mercy !
Old Cuirassier , groaning with outstretched hands —
Horrible agonized hands with bloody wrists !—
Mercy ! Poor little Private of the Guards ,
Who slowly raise your livid face to mine !
Look not upon me with those glazing eyes !
Why do you creep upon me through the gloom ?
God ! ‘ Tis as though you strove to utter cries !
Why do you all suck in a mighty breath ?
Why do you open horror-sated lips ?
What will you cry ?— What ?— What ?
Ah ! Pardon , for the glory 's sake !— I thank you .
I understand . I am the expiation .
All was not paid , and I complete the price .
‘ Twas fated I should seek his battle-field ,
And here , above the multitudinous dead ,
Be the white victim , growing daily whiter ,
Renouncing , praying , asking but to suffer ,
Yearning toward heaven , like sacrificial incense !
And while betwixt the heavens and this field
I am outstretched with all my soul and body ,
Father , I feel the shuddering furrows rise ,
I feel the hill upheaved beneath my feet
To lift me gently to the stooping heavens !
‘ Tis meet and right the battle-field should offer
This sacrifice , that henceforth it may bear
Pure and unstained its name of Victory .
Wagram , behold me ! Ransom of old days ,
Son , offered for , alas ! how many sons !
Above the dreadful haze wherein thou stirrest ,
Uplift me , Wagram , in thy scarlet hands !
It must be so ! I know it ! Feel it ! Will it !
The breath of death has rustled through my hair !
The shudder of death has passed athwart my soul !
I am all white : a sacramental Host !
What more reproaches can they hurl , O Father ,
Against our hapless fate ?— Oh , hush ! I add
In silence Schönbrunn to Saint Helena !—
‘ Tis done !— But if the Eaglet is resigned
To perish like the innocent , yielding swan ,
Nailed in the gloom above some lofty gate ,
He must become the high and holy signal
That scares the ravens and calls back the eagles .
There must be no more meanings in the field ,
Nor dreadful writhings in the underwood .
Bear on thy wings , O whirlwind of the plain ,
The shouts of conquerors and songs of triumph !
lg.stage: A proud and joyous clamor arises in the distance .
