lg.l: I 've changed the meanings into trumpet blasts !
lg.stage: The wind wafts vague sounds of trumpet-calls .
lg.l: I 've earned the right to see what crawled and writhed ,
Suddenly leap into a phantom charge !

div.stage: Noise as of a cavalcade . The VOICES , which before were lugubrious , now call to each other with commands and signals .
The drums of the wind beat the charge .

lg.l: The pomp and pageantry of battle ,
The dust that 's raised by charging cavalry !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The wild laughter of the fierce Hussars !

lg.stage: In a shout of epic laughter .
lg.l: Ha ! Ha !
Now , Goddess of the hundred mouths ,
Victory , from whose lips I 've torn the gag ,
Sing in the distance !
Form battalions !

lg.stage: Upright in the first glow of dawn .
lg.l: Glory ! O God , to battle in this blaze !

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Fire !— Half-columns , by your right , advance !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: To battle in this tumult you commanded ! O Father ! Father !—

div.stage: Amid the noise of battle , which is dying away in the distance , a haughty , metallic voice is heard , preceded and followed by a roll of drums .

lg.stage: In wild delirium , drawing his sword .
lg.l: I come !— I fight !— Laugh , fife ! and banners wave !
Fix bayonets ! Fall on the whitecoats ! Forward !

div.stage: And while the dream-sounds die away toward the right , swept by the wind , all of a sudden , on the left , a real military band bursts out ; and abruptly , like the awaking out of a dream , there is the contrast between the furious battle-music of the French , and a tame march of Schubert 's Austrian and dance-like , drawing near in the rosy glow of the morning .

lg.stage: Who has turned with a shudder .
lg.l: What white thing marching through the dawning day ?
The Austrian Infantry !
lg.stage: Beside himself , and urging along imaginary Grenadiers .
lg.l: Ha ! Up ! and at them !
The enemy !— Fall on them !— - Crush them !
Follow on ! Follow on ! We 'll pass across their bodies !

div.stage: With his sword high he rushes at the first ranks of an Austrian regiment which appears on the road .

lg.stage: Throwing himself on the DUKE and stopping him .
lg.l: For God 's sake . Prince !— This is your regiment !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: As if awakening .Ah —? This is my —?He falls back ; passes his hand across his forehead , and gazes wildly at the white soldiers who march past to the sound of the fife . He sees his destiny , and accepts it . The arm he had raised for the charge sinks slowly , his fist falls on his hip ; his sword falls into the regulation position , and , stiff as an automaton , with a toneless and mechanical voice , the voice of an Austrian officer , he cries :Halt ! Front turn ! Eyes right !

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS AS THE DRILL BEGINS

div.head: THE SIXTH ACT

stage.stage: The DUKE 'S bedroom at Schönbrunn . The walls are covered with Gobelin tapestry . Through folding-doors on the left there is a glimpse of the china-cabinet . There are also folding-doors on the right and in the centre . Empire furniture . A little camp-bedstead stands almost in the middle of the room . Many bunches of violets are scattered about .

The DUKE is discovered buried in a deep arm-chair , his fingers idly toying with a large bunch of violets . The ARCHDUCHESS is offering him a glass of milk . DOCTOR MALFATTI is seated at the back of the room .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: You ?— Why , I thought you ill !

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: They 've let me come . Thank heaven !— And you ?

lg.l: Why , if you leave your sick-bed
I must be worse indeed .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Come , now , that 's nonsense ! You know you 're better .She examines the cup the DUKE hands her .There , that 's finished . She calls the DOCTOR , who has been seated at the back of the room . ] His Highness drank his milk .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: How good it was of him !

lg.l: How hard —
When I had dreamed of history 's reward ,
And when ambition seared my soul — How hard ,
To be content with praise for drinking milk !
lg.stage: To the violets on his pillow .
lg.l: Oh , ball of freshness laid upon my fever .
Dear flowers that bring the Spring into my room —!
Hush ! As an act of gratitude to God
For saving us — since both of us are better —
I am to take the Sacrament this morning ,
I think — I hope — Franz , will you not come , too ?

lg.stage: After a long look at her .
lg.l: Ah , now I see the pious trick you 'd play me !
This is the end !

div.stage: He rises .

lg.l: I knew you 'd say so !
Think !
The etiquette —!
You know
You cannot be deceived . When Austrian Princes
Receive the —
Oh ! not that mournful word !—
All the Imperial Family must be present .
But we 're alone ! I 've had an altar
Placed in that cabinet ; and look about you :
No sign of an Archduke or an Archduchess .
The Prelate says the Mass for you and me ;
‘ Tis but the ordinary Mass ; you see
This Sacrament is not —

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: Well ? Are you coming ? Hark ! The Mass begins !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: ‘ Tis true , the illustrious audience should be present .

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: We 've but the Prelate and the Acolyte .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: So , then , I am to have a respite —?

div.stage: They go out .
As soon as they have disappeared , the opposite door opens and GENERAL HARTMANN ushers in the COURT .

lg.l: Come !
Place yourselves here ; and when , with humbled eyes
The Duke is prostrate to receive the Host —
Hush !
In that awful moment
When nothing can distract a Christian 's thoughts
I 'll softly ope the door . For one brief second
Your Highnesses will see his golden head ;
Then I shall close the door , and thus he 'll rise ,
Not knowing he received , before the Court ,
As usage dictates , the Viaticum .

lg.stage: Who has just brought in the COUNTESS and THERESA .
lg.l: They have permitted me to place you
Behind the Imperial Family , and thus ,
Above the heads of Princes bent in prayer ,
O'er whom mysterious fate is hovering ,
And pallid children clasping pitiful hands ,
For the last time you 'll see the dying Duke .

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: Oh , thank you , thank you , sir !

lg.l: Let no one stir
When the door opens !

div.stage: All kneel .

lg.l: Well ,
Prince ? Is there nothing you regret ?
No , nothing .
I did my duty . Madam — often suffered
While doing it — for my country 's weal , my master 's ,
And in defence of ancient privilege .

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: The Agnus Dei .To HARTMANN , who very gently opens the door a very little way and peers through .Let not the door creak as you open it !

lg.l: None . But he was a noble Prince . I kneel
To-day not only to the Lamb of God !

sp.speaker: HARTMANN
sp.p: The Prelate has uncovered the Ciborium !

sp.speaker: HARTMANN
sp.p: Rigid silence ! I 'm about to open !

lg.l: Oh !

div.stage: He silently thrusts the wings of the folding-doors open . All the COURT is prostrate . There is a vague glimpse of candle light . A moment 's pause of profound emotion and silence . THERESA slowly rises to look across the kneeling forms ; she looks and sees .

lg.stage: Amid the sobs which overmaster her .
lg.l: Oh ! to behold him thus !

div.stage: Movement . GENERAL HARTMANN has swiftly closed the doors . Everybody has risen .

All have hurried toward the door on the right , but the door on the left opens quickly ; the DUKE appears on the threshold and sees them all standing before him . After a long look which takes in the situation :

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Ah !— I see .He draws himself up , and comes toward them with sudden majesty .I thank the breaking heart that broke the silence ; Let her who wept feel no remorse for weeping : They had no right to rob me of my death .To the ARCHDUKES and ARCHDUCHESSES , who withdraw respectfully .But leave me now , my Austrian family ! “ My son was born a Frenchman ; until death Let him remember that . ” And I remember .

div.stage: To the PRINCES who are leaving .

lg.l: Whose was the breaking heart ?

lg.stage: Who has remained humbly on her knees in a corner .
lg.l: My Lord —!

lg.stage: Approaching her , and speaking with great tenderness .
lg.l: You are not very reasonable ! Once
Over your book you wept to see me live
An Austrian Prince with flowers in my coat ;
And now you weep because that life has killed me .
Madam ,
You hid this from me . Why ?
Who brought you both to see me ?

div.stage: THERESA and the COUNTESS look at the ARCHDUCHESS .

lg.l: You ?
Women have loved me as they love a child —
lg.stage: The THREE WOMEN make a gesture of protest .
lg.l: Ah , yes ! The child they pity , spoil , and shelter —
And with maternal fingers , on my brow
Still sought the golden curls which Lawrence painted .

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: No , no ! We knew the struggles of your soul !

lg.l: And history itself will not record
The Prince whose soul was seared with all ambitions ,
But see the solemn , rosy , fair-haired child
Tricked out in laces in his little goat-cart ,
Holding the globe as ‘ twere an air-balloon .
Speak to me ! I am here ! Give me a word
To soothe remorse , for through no fault of mine
I was too small beside your mighty dreams .
I have the thriftless conscience of a bird !
The tinkling bells that jangle in my brain
Have never ceased till now . Look at me now !
Speak to me now ! Forgive me now !
O God !
Inspire me with the deep , yet tender word
With which a son forgives his mother .
Franz ,
The cradle which you asked them for last night —

div.stage: He goes out to fetch it .

lg.l: Ah , my Lord Chancellor , I die
Too soon for you ; and you should weep .
I was your weapon and my death disarms you !
Europe , which never dared to say you nay ,
When you were he who could unchain the Eaglet ,
Listening to-morrow , will take heart , and say
“ I do not hear it stirring in its cage ! ”

div.stage: The great enamelled cradle is brought in .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: The cradle Paris gave me ! My splendid cradle , Prudhon 's masterpiece ! Amidst its gold and mother-o ’ - pearl I slept , A babe , whose christening was a coronation . Place it beside this little bed , whereon My Father slept when victory fanned his slumbers . Closer ! until its laces graze the sheets . Alas ! how near my cradle to my death-bed !He points to the gap between the cradle and the bed .And all my life lies in that narrow space !

lg.l: In that gap , too narrow and too dark ,
Fate ne'er let fall a single pin of glory .
Lay me upon the bed .
Ah , I was greater in my cradle , than
I am upon this bed ; and women rocked me —
Yes , I had three to rock me , and they sang
Their strange old songs : dear songs of Mistress Marchand !
Oh , who will lull me now with cradle-songs ?

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: Is not your mother here to sing to you ?

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Do you know any songs of France ?

lg.l: And you ?
Oh , sing below your breath .
“ The rain falls , Shepherdess ” and “ May is come , ”
And sing “ Upon the bridge that spans the Rhone , ”
That I may sleep , rocked on the people 's fancy .
There was a song I used to love ; sing that :—
There was a little man ,
And he was clad in gray —

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: Break , tender heart , as broke the heart of iron —

sp.speaker: THE COUNTESS
sp.p: A crystal , shattered by a brazen echo —

sp.speaker: THE ARCHDUCHESS
sp.p: A harp-string , shattered by a battle-song —

sp.speaker: THERESA
sp.p: A lily sinking silently on laurels .

sp.speaker: THE DOCTOR
sp.p: My Lord is very ill . Stand more apart .

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: Alas , his head grows heavy on my shoulder !

lg.l: The horses ! horses !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Horses ! that I may ride to meet my father !

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: Will you not let me wipe away your tears ?

lg.l: No , for the Victories , my sisters — Lo !
I see them ! see them ! in a headlong flight
Draw nigh to lave their glory in my tears !
Nothing . Did I speak ?
Hush ! Father , that 's our secret : yours and mine !—
My funeral will be ugly . Mumbling women ;
Lackeys with torches ; droning Capuchins ;
And then they 'll lock me in their crypt — and then —
Oh ! Superhuman !—
And then , official mourning for six weeks .
He snatches at the cradle 's lace , as if
To make a winding sheet —
It will be ugly —
I must remember how they christen better
In Paris than they bury in Vienna .
General Hartmann !

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Yes — while I wait For death , I 'll rock my childhood —He hands GENERAL HARTMANN a book from under his pillow .Here —GENERAL HARTMANN takes the book . The DUKE falls to rocking the cradle .I rock My past — I rock my past — As though The Duke of Reichstadt rocked the King of Rome . General — I marked a place —

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: Good . While I 'm dying , read aloud —

sp.speaker: MARIA LOUISA
sp.p: No , no ! You shall not die !

lg.stage: Standing at the foot of the bed and reading .
lg.l: “ Toward seven o'clock the Calvary appear ,
Forming the head of the procession — ”

lg.stage: Falling on her knees in a paroxysm of sobs .
lg.l: Franz !
“ The people , shaken with great sobs of joy ,
Utter a shout :— ‘ Long live the King of Rome ! ’ — ”
“ And the guns salute ; the Cardinal
Receives their Majesties , and so the pageant
Moves up the aisle as ancient rules prescribe .
The Ushers , Kings-at-Arms , their chief , the pages ,
The various officers of the staff , the — ”

div.stage: Noticing that the DUKE has closed his eyes , he stops .

lg.l: Yes ?
“ The Chamberlains , the Prefects of the palace ,
Ministers , Masters of the Horse — ”
HARTMANN .
“ Marshals of France , Grand Eagles ; and Princess
Aldobrandini holds the chrisom-cloth ;
The Countesses Vilain and de Beauvau
Bring in the ewer and the salt-cellar — ”
Read on , sir . Mother — mother — lift me up .

div.stage: MARIA LOUISA , assisted by the PRELATE and DOCTOR MALFATTI , raises him on his pillows .

lg.l: “ Then the Grand Duke , who took on this occasion
The Austrian Emperor 's place as Sponsor : then
Queen Hortense , and the Imperial Godmother ;
Lastly , the King of Rome , borne by Her Grace ,
The Duchess of Montesquieu . His Majesty ,
Whose healthy mien the crowd observed with joy ,
Wore a great silver mantle , lined with ermine ,
Whose train His Grace the Duke of Valmy bore .
Princes — ”
“ Kings — ”
Omit
The Kings . The end , sir ; read the end —
“ And when — ”
The last agony .
“ And when the Herald thrice within the choir
Had cried ‘ Long live the King of Rome ! ’ before
They handed back the baby to its nurse ,
The Emperor gently took it from — ”

div.stage: He hesitates , with a glance at MARIA LOUISA .

sp.speaker: THE DUKE
sp.p: With infinite nobility and placing his hand with tender forgiveness on the head of MARIA LOUISA , who is kneeling at his side .The Empress !

sp.speaker: HARTMANN
sp.p: “ And raised it to receive the acclamation . The loud — ”

lg.l: Mamma !
François !
Napoleon !

div.stage: He sinks back .

lg.l: “ The loud Te Deum filled the sanctuary .
And all that night , throughout the realm of France ,
With equal pomp , solemnity , and joy — ”

lg.stage: Putting his hand on the GENERAL 'S arm .
lg.l: Dead !

div.stage: Silence . The GENERAL closes the book .

sp.speaker: METTERNICH
sp.p: Clothe him in his Austrian uniform .

div.stage: CURTAIN .
